Financial crisis unfolds in real-time through digital media. Airbnb founded, beginning sharing economy's physical space digitization. Physical retail continues collapse (Circuit City bankruptcy). The smartphone becomes primary computing device for millions. Continuous connectivity becomes cultural expectation. The boundary between online and offline blurs toward irrelevance.

2010.description: Δw plateaus at near-total mediation. iPad launches, creating tablet computing category. Instagram launches, emphasizing image-based social media. Smartphone ownership accelerates past 25%. Internet hosts exceed 750 million. Facebook reaches 500 million users. Twitter becomes real-time news source. Netflix streaming surpasses DVD by mail. E-books reach 8% of book market. The Arab Spring demonstrates social media's revolutionary potential. Wikileaks releases demonstrate information's resistance to containment. FarmVille demonstrates casual gaming's massive reach. Physical retail continues decline; shopping moves online. Dating apps begin transforming romantic introduction from embodied to screened encounter. The smartphone ensures constant connectivity and continuous partial attention. Physical presence becomes one mode among many rather than default reality.

2012.description: Δw approaches asymptotic maximum. Facebook reaches 1 billion users. Smartphone ownership reaches 50% of American adults. Instagram sells to Facebook for $1 billion. Oculus VR founded, reviving virtual reality. MOOC platforms (Coursera, edX) promise education's digital transformation. Tablets proliferate. E-books reach 23% of market. The Sandy Hook shooting amplifies debates about media coverage of violence. Hurricane Sandy demonstrates social media's disaster communication role. Online advertising surpasses print. Netflix produces original content (House of Cards, 2013). Tinder transforms dating into gamified swiping. Physical retail closures accelerate. The smartphone becomes primary camera, replacing dedicated devices. Constant connectivity becomes cultural norm. Human attention becomes scarce resource extracted by competing platforms.
key_manifestations: Oculus VR founding reviving virtual reality

2014.description: Δw maintains near-total level as digital becomes invisible infrastructure. Facebook acquires WhatsApp for $19 billion and Oculus for $2 billion. Smartphone ownership reaches 64% of American adults. Amazon Echo introduces voice computing. Streaming surpasses physical music sales. Uber valued at $40 billion, demonstrating app-mediated physical services. Ice Bucket Challenge demonstrates viral social media fundraising. Net neutrality debates intensify. Twitch sold to Amazon for $970 million, demonstrating video game streaming's reach. E-commerce approaches $300 billion annually. Physical retail continues decline. Dating apps become primary meeting method for new couples. The screen becomes default interface for commerce, communication, entertainment, information, and social connection. Physical presence becomes notable exception rather than default experience mode.

2016.description: Δw approaches total mediation. Pokémon Go briefly demonstrates augmented reality's mass appeal, overlaying digital on physical. VR headsets reach consumer market (Oculus Rift, HTC Vive). Smartphone ownership reaches 77% of American adults. Facebook reaches 1.8 billion users. Netflix reaches 75 million global subscribers. The presidential election demonstrates social media's political influence and misinformation's spread. Fake news becomes cultural concern. Amazon delivery and streaming reshape commerce and entertainment. Cord-cutting accelerates as streaming replaces cable. Physical retail crisis deepens. Instagram Stories copies Snapchat, demonstrating ephemeral content's appeal. Work increasingly occurs remotely through digital tools. Human attention becomes primary commodity. The physical world serves primarily as backdrop for screened experience.
key_manifestations: Consumer VR headset launches (Oculus Rift, HTC Vive)
2016 election social media influence and misinformation

2018.description: Δw remains at near-total level as concerns about digital dominance mount. Screen time concerns drive digital wellness movement. Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal reveals data exploitation. GDPR implemented in Europe, attempting privacy regulation. Smartphone ownership reaches 81% of American adults. Instagram reaches 1 billion users. Fortnite demonstrates gaming's cultural dominance with 125 million players. Netflix reaches 130 million subscribers. E-commerce approaches $500 billion annually. Physical retail apocalypse continues with major bankruptcies. Remote work tools mature. Dating apps dominate romantic introduction. Virtual assistants (Alexa, Siri, Google) proliferate. The backlash against digital dominance begins without slowing adoption. Physical presence becomes increasingly rare and notable. Human flourishing concerns mount as screen time displaces embodied experience.
key_manifestations: Screen time and digital wellness concerns mounting

2020.description: Δw culminates in pandemic-accelerated disembodiment. COVID-19 pandemic forces unprecedented migration to virtual existence. Zoom becomes verb; video conferencing replaces physical meeting. Remote work becomes default for knowledge workers. E-commerce jumps from 16% to 21% of retail in months. Streaming services surge (Netflix reaches 200 million subscribers). Social isolation enforced; digital connection becomes only connection. Telemedicine adoption leaps. Virtual events replace physical gatherings. VR adoption accelerates. Education moves online. Physical presence becomes health risk rather than default. The pandemic completes digital disembodiment's long trajectory from telegraph through telephone through television through internet through smartphone. Thiel's 'bits vs atoms' divergence reaches maximum expression. Human activity has migrated decisively from embodied space to screen-mediated simulation. The physical world remains essential for biology but increasingly optional for social, commercial, and cultural life.
key_manifestations: Zoom becoming verb for video communication
Remote work becoming default for knowledge workers
E-commerce jumping from 16% to 21% of retail

12_secularization_disenchantment.name: Secularization and Disenchantment
12_secularization_disenchantment.description: Weber's 'disenchantment of the world' - the progressive evacuation of transcendent meaning from nature, society, and self. This cluster tracks the decline of religious authority, the rise of scientific naturalism, and the loss of cosmic significance that once oriented human life. Not merely declining church attendance but the deeper transformation: from a world saturated with sacred meaning to one governed by instrumental reason. The essay invokes Nietzsche's 'God is dead' not as theological claim but as diagnosis of moral foundations' collapse - when transcendent standards erode, beauty loses its 'own verification.'

1880.description: High Victorian religiosity maintains cultural dominance despite Darwin's challenge two decades prior. Churches remain central to social life across Europe and America. The sacred canopy holds, though cracks appear in intellectual circles.
key_manifestations: Dwight L. Moody's urban revival campaigns reach millions in Anglo-American cities
Pope Leo XIII issues Aeterni Patris (1879) reviving Thomistic philosophy against modernism
Robert Elsmere by Mrs. Humphry Ward not yet published - clergy still command respect
Matthew Arnold's 'Dover Beach' (1867) circulates as minority dissent against sea of faith

1882.description: Nietzsche publishes The Gay Science with 'God is dead' parable. German higher criticism of Bible reaches English readers. The erosion is intellectual before becoming popular.
key_manifestations: Friedrich Nietzsche, Die frohliche Wissenschaft (1882) - 'God is dead' parable of the madman
Julius Wellhausen's Prolegomena zur Geschichte Israels challenges Mosaic authorship
Charles Darwin dies (1882) as scientific naturalism's founding figure
Society for Psychical Research founded - attempts to scientifically verify spiritual claims

1884.description: Religious institutions adapt to industrial modernity. Social gospel movement reframes Christianity's mission. Herbert Spencer's evolutionary philosophy gains popular following.
key_manifestations: Washington Gladden's Applied Christianity pioneers social gospel approach
Herbert Spencer's synthetic philosophy reaches peak influence
Oxford English Dictionary begins publication - secular monument to rational knowledge
Fabian Society founded with secular socialist vision

1886.description: Nietzsche's Beyond Good and Evil challenges Christian morality's foundations. Labor movements provide alternative meaning-systems. Religion faces competition for souls.
key_manifestations: Friedrich Nietzsche, Jenseits von Gut und Bose (1886) - systematic critique of Christian values
Haymarket affair (1886) - martyrdom narrative outside religious framework
American Federation of Labor founded - secular solidarity
Robert Louis Stevenson's Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde - secular psychology of evil

1888.description: Nietzsche completes his most direct assault on Christianity. Twilight of the Idols, The Antichrist written. Yet his influence remains confined to avant-garde circles.
key_manifestations: Friedrich Nietzsche writes The Antichrist (1888) - Christianity as 'curse upon mankind'
Edward Bellamy's Looking Backward imagines secular utopia
Theosophical Society spreads alternative spirituality challenging Christian monopoly
Friedrich Nietzsche, Gotzen-Dammerung (Twilight of the Idols) composed

1890.description: Psychology and anthropology emerge as sciences studying religion as human phenomenon. James George Frazer begins comparative mythology. Religion becomes object of study rather than unquestioned framework.
key_manifestations: William James's Principles of Psychology (1890) - naturalistic account of consciousness
James George Frazer begins The Golden Bough research - religion as primitive survival
Nietzsche's mental collapse (1889) - prophet of disenchantment silenced
Leo Tolstoy's spiritual crisis narratives circulate

1892.description: The Golden Bough's first edition treats Christianity as one myth among many. Socialist and anarchist movements offer secular eschatologies. Working-class alienation from churches grows.
key_manifestations: James George Frazer, The Golden Bough first edition (1890) gains readership
People's Party (Populist) offers agrarian secular salvation in America
Emile Durkheim begins sociology of religion at Bordeaux
Pope Leo XIII's Rerum Novarum (1891) - Church responds to socialist challenge

1894.description: Higher criticism enters mainstream theological education. Seminaries divide between modernists and fundamentalists. The conflict that will define American Protestantism takes shape.
key_manifestations: Charles Briggs heresy trial at Union Theological Seminary (1893)
Parliament of World's Religions at Chicago World's Fair (1893) - religious pluralism displayed
Thomas Huxley's Collected Essays spread scientific naturalism
Aubrey Beardsley's decadent art suggests post-Christian aestheticism

1896.description: Andrew Dickson White's A History of the Warfare of Science with Theology frames religion-science relationship as conflict. American research universities expand secular knowledge production.
key_manifestations: Andrew Dickson White, A History of the Warfare of Science with Theology (1896)
William James delivers 'The Will to Believe' defending religious option
Theodor Herzl's Der Judenstaat - secular nationalism as Jewish salvation
John Dewey at Chicago develops naturalistic philosophy of education

1898.description: Durkheim's sociological approach treats religion as social fact. Imperial expansion brings contact with world religions, relativizing Christian claims. The sacred is explained by the social.
key_manifestations: Spanish-American War - American messianism in secular-imperial form
H.G. Wells's The War of the Worlds - cosmic indifference to humanity
Dreyfus Affair exposes religious-secular tensions in France

1900.description: Fin-de-siecle anxiety pervades. Freud offers secular interpretation of soul. Nietzsche's works gain posthumous influence. The twentieth century dawns with transcendence in question.
key_manifestations: Sigmund Freud, Die Traumdeutung (1899/1900) - secular hermeneutics of psyche
Nietzsche dies (1900) as his influence begins ascent
Max Planck's quantum hypothesis - nature more strange than sacred cosmology imagined
Leslie Stephen's English Utilitarians - secular moral philosophy

1902.description: William James's Varieties of Religious Experience approaches religion pragmatically and psychologically. Religion is real because it has effects, not because of transcendent validation.
key_manifestations: William James, The Varieties of Religious Experience (1902) Gifford Lectures
Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness - moral void at civilization's heart
Bertrand Russell begins mathematical logic project - reason without revelation
Education Act 1902 (UK) - state assumes religious education oversight

1904.description: Max Weber begins publishing The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism, showing how religious rationalization produces secular rationality. Religion contains seeds of its own transcendence.
key_manifestations: Max Weber, 'Die protestantische Ethik' begins publication (1904-05)
France's Combes government expels religious orders
Russo-Japanese War - Asian nation defeats Christian empire
G.E. Moore's Principia Ethica - ethics without theology

1906.description: France legally separates church and state. Albert Schweitzer's Quest of the Historical Jesus shows each age projects its values onto Christ. The sacred becomes historical artifact.
key_manifestations: French law of 1905 separating church and state takes effect
Albert Schweitzer, Von Reimarus zu Wrede (Quest of Historical Jesus, 1906)
San Francisco earthquake - nature's indifference to prayer
Upton Sinclair's The Jungle - secular muckraking as moral crusade

1908.description: The Fundamentals publication begins (1910 forthcoming). Social Christianity reaches institutional peak. Religious reform and reaction both respond to secularizing pressure.
key_manifestations: Walter Rauschenbusch, Christianity and the Social Crisis (1907) - social gospel peak
Catholic modernist crisis - Pius X's Pascendi condemns modernism (1907)
William James's Pragmatism (1907) - truth without transcendence
Georges Sorel's Reflections on Violence - secular myth

1910.description: The Fundamentals begin publication as defensive response to modernism. Durkheim's Elementary Forms reduces religion to social function. Sacred and profane become sociological categories.
key_manifestations: The Fundamentals: A Testimony to the Truth begins publication (1910-1915)
Edinburgh World Missionary Conference - ecumenical response to secular challenge
Bertrand Russell and A.N. Whitehead's Principia Mathematica (1910) - logic without theology
William James dies - pragmatist approach to religion influential

1912.description: Durkheim publishes Les Formes elementaires de la vie religieuse. The Titanic sinks, challenging human mastery and providential protection alike. Secular tragedy replaces divine judgment.
key_manifestations: Emile Durkheim, Les Formes elementaires de la vie religieuse (1912)
RMS Titanic sinks - technology's limits, providence's silence
Carl Jung breaks with Freud - competing secular psychologies of soul
Rudolf Steiner founds Anthroposophy - esoteric alternative to both religion and materialism

1914.description: World War I begins, shattering confidence in Christian civilization. Churches on both sides bless their nations' arms. The scandal of Christian fratricide begins disenchantment's acceleration.
key_manifestations: Outbreak of World War I - Christian nations slaughter each other
Churches on all sides proclaim their cause righteous
Pope Benedict XV's peace efforts marginalized
Bertrand Russell's pacifism - secular moral witness against religious nationalism

1916.description: Verdun and the Somme produce industrialized mass death. Theodicy becomes impossible for many. Chaplains struggle with meaningless suffering. War poets articulate secular despair.
key_manifestations: Battle of the Somme - 60,000 British casualties in one day
Verdun's ten-month slaughter defies providential explanation
Wilfred Owen, Siegfried Sassoon begin war poetry - secular witness to horror
Easter Rising in Ireland - nationalism replaces or absorbs religious identity

1918.description: War ends with 17 million dead. Spanish flu kills tens of millions more. Russian Revolution offers atheist alternative. Oswald Spengler announces West's decline. Transcendent meaning evacuates.
key_manifestations: Armistice ends World War I - 17 million dead
Spanish flu pandemic (1918-1920) - mass death, divine silence
Oswald Spengler, Der Untergang des Abendlandes (Decline of the West, 1918)
Bolshevik Revolution establishes state atheism in Russia

1920.description: Postwar disillusionment pervades Western culture. Karl Barth's Romans commentary reasserts transcendence against liberal theology. Fundamentalism and neo-orthodoxy both react to secularization.
key_manifestations: Karl Barth, Der Romerbrief second edition (1922 forthcoming) - neo-orthodox reaction
H.L. Mencken's journalism mocks American religious culture
Women gain vote in US - secular suffrage movement succeeds
League of Nations - secular international order attempted

1922.description: T.S. Eliot's The Waste Land diagnoses spiritual desolation. Karl Barth's Romans commentary proclaims God's radical otherness. Both register transcendence's retreat in contrasting ways.
key_manifestations: T.S. Eliot, The Waste Land (1922) - 'I will show you fear in a handful of dust'
Karl Barth, Der Romerbrief second edition (1922) - dialectical theology
James Joyce, Ulysses (1922) - secular epic of ordinary consciousness
Ludwig Wittgenstein, Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus - whereof one cannot speak

1924.description: Soviet Union intensifies antireligious campaigns. American fundamentalism mobilizes against evolution in schools. Religion becomes battlefield rather than shared horizon.
key_manifestations: Lenin dies - Soviet cult of personality as secular religion
Immigration Act 1924 restricts Catholic and Jewish immigration to US
E.M. Forster, A Passage to India - religious pluralism as problem

1926.description: Scopes trial (1925) makes fundamentalism appear backward to educated opinion. Rudolf Bultmann begins program of demythologizing. Religion must accommodate scientific worldview or resist it.
key_manifestations: Scopes 'Monkey Trial' (1925) - evolution vs. fundamentalism publicized
Rudolf Bultmann begins demythologizing program at Marburg
Ernest Hemingway, The Sun Also Rises (1926) - lost generation's secular despair
Martin Heidegger, Sein und Zeit (1927 forthcoming) - existence without transcendent ground

1928.description: Heidegger's Being and Time offers existential analysis without theological framework. Al Smith's Catholic presidential candidacy exposes American Protestant anxieties. Secular existence confronted philosophically.
key_manifestations: Martin Heidegger, Sein und Zeit (1927) - atheistic existentialism emerges
Al Smith's presidential campaign - anti-Catholic sentiment revealed
Margaret Mead, Coming of Age in Samoa - cultural relativism of morals
D.H. Lawrence, Lady Chatterley's Lover - sexuality without sin

1930.description: Great Depression begins, testing theodicy again. Freud's Civilization and Its Discontents sees religion as illusion. Economic catastrophe produces both religious seeking and secular radicalism.
key_manifestations: Stock market crash (1929) and Great Depression onset
Sigmund Freud, Das Unbehagen in der Kultur (Civilization and Its Discontents, 1930)
Pope Pius XI, Casti Connubii condemns contraception
Logical positivism declares metaphysics meaningless - Vienna Circle

1932.description: Reinhold Niebuhr's Moral Man and Immoral Society critiques naive social gospel. Aldous Huxley's Brave New World envisions religion replaced by soma. Christian realism and dystopian secularism both emerge.
key_manifestations: Reinhold Niebuhr, Moral Man and Immoral Society (1932)
Aldous Huxley, Brave New World (1932) - religion obsolete in techno-dystopia
Franklin Roosevelt elected - secular New Deal salvation

1934.description: German Christians accommodate Nazism. Barmen Declaration resists totalitarian claims. The Confessing Church demonstrates both religion's corruptibility and capacity for resistance to secular ideology.
key_manifestations: Barmen Declaration (1934) - Confessing Church resists Nazi co-optation
German Christians movement - religion accommodates totalitarianism
Soviet antireligious campaigns intensify under Stalin
Ruth Benedict, Patterns of Culture - cultural relativism spreads

1936.description: Spanish Civil War aligns Catholic Church with Franco. A.J. Ayer's Language, Truth and Logic declares theological statements meaningless. Religion seen as either reactionary or nonsensical.
key_manifestations: Spanish Civil War begins - Church aligns with Franco against Republic
A.J. Ayer, Language, Truth and Logic (1936) - logical positivism popularized
Keynes's General Theory - secular economics as salvation
Walter Benjamin, 'The Work of Art' - aura's decay in mechanical reproduction

1938.description: Kristallnacht exposes Christian civilization's failure to protect Jews. Jean-Paul Sartre develops atheistic existentialism. War approaches, revealing religion's inability to prevent catastrophe.
key_manifestations: Kristallnacht (1938) - churches largely silent on antisemitic violence
Jean-Paul Sartre, La Nausee (1938) - atheist existentialism in fiction
Mit brennender Sorge - Pius XI's belated critique of Nazism
Orson Welles's War of the Worlds broadcast - secular apocalypse panic

1940.description: World War II engulfs Europe. Churches face complicity in fascism or collaboration under occupation. The Holocaust begins, ultimate challenge to theodicy. Transcendence retreats before industrialized evil.
key_manifestations: Fall of France - Catholic nation collapses
Battle of Britain - 'Christian civilization' fights alone
Reinhold Niebuhr argues for intervention against isolationism
Arthur Koestler, Darkness at Noon - totalitarianism's secular faith

1942.description: Holocaust's systematic nature becomes clear. Wannsee Conference plans Final Solution. Albert Camus's The Stranger presents absurd existence. Where was God at Auschwitz becomes inescapable question.
key_manifestations: T.S. Eliot's Four Quartets seeks transcendence amid war
C.S. Lewis's Broadcast Talks (later Mere Christianity) - popular apologetics

1944.description: Dietrich Bonhoeffer writes of 'religionless Christianity' from Nazi prison. Jean-Paul Sartre systematizes existentialist atheism. Liberation approaches through military not miraculous means.
key_manifestations: Dietrich Bonhoeffer's prison letters - 'world come of age' without religion
D-Day invasion - secular planning, not providence, determines outcome
Jean-Paul Sartre working on Being and Nothingness
Friedrich Hayek, The Road to Serfdom - secular liberal alternative

1946.description: War ends with atomic bombs and Holocaust revealed. Existentialism dominates European thought. Nuremberg trials establish secular human rights framework. Transcendence seems impossible after Auschwitz.
key_manifestations: Nuremberg Trials - secular justice for crimes against humanity
Jean-Paul Sartre, 'Existentialism is a Humanism' lecture (1945)
Simone de Beauvoir, The Ethics of Ambiguity - secular ethics
Atomic age begins - human power to destroy creation

1948.description: World Council of Churches founded, ecumenism responds to secularization. Universal Declaration of Human Rights provides secular moral framework. Cold War begins with atheist communism as enemy.
key_manifestations: World Council of Churches founded in Amsterdam (1948)
Universal Declaration of Human Rights - secular morality codified
State of Israel founded - secular Zionism realized
Alfred Kinsey, Sexual Behavior in the Human Male - sexuality scientifically studied

1950.description: Postwar religious revival begins in America. Billy Graham's crusades draw millions. Cold War framed as spiritual battle against godless communism. Suburban church-building boom begins.
key_manifestations: Billy Graham's Los Angeles Crusade (1949) launches national ministry
Pius XII, Humani Generis - Catholic response to modernism
Senator McCarthy invokes Christian civilization against communism

1952.description: American religious revival peaks. Eisenhower's civil religion. Norman Vincent Peale's positive thinking Christianity. Religion becomes patriotic duty against communism. Yet this is civic religion, not transcendence recovered.
key_manifestations: Norman Vincent Peale, The Power of Positive Thinking (1952)
Eisenhower elected, famously says 'our form of government makes no sense unless it is founded in a deeply felt religious faith'
Reinhold Niebuhr, The Irony of American History critiques civil religion

1954.description: 'Under God' added to Pledge of Allegiance. Billy Graham advises presidents. Church membership at historic American highs. But critics note religion's therapeutic and nationalistic function, not transcendent orientation.
key_manifestations: 'Under God' added to Pledge of Allegiance (1954)
Billy Graham, Hour of Decision radio program at peak influence
C.G. Jung's Answer to Job - psychological approach to religion
Brown v. Board of Education - secular law advances justice churches failed to achieve

1956.description: 'In God We Trust' becomes official US motto. Will Herberg's Protestant-Catholic-Jew analyzes American civil religion. Religion thrives but as social identity, not transcendent orientation. Peak of 1950s religiosity.
key_manifestations: 'In God We Trust' adopted as US national motto (1956)
Will Herberg, Protestant-Catholic-Jew (1955) - religion as American identity
Hungarian Revolution crushed - 'godless communism' villain confirmed
Allen Ginsberg, 'Howl' - beat spirituality rejects mainline religion

1958.description: Sputnik launches space age, science ascendant. Pope Pius XII dies, John XXIII elected, reform anticipated. American religiosity peaks but critics note its shallowness. The long secular 1960s approach.
key_manifestations: Sputnik (1957) launches space race - science as salvation
Pope John XXIII elected (1958) - reform anticipated
National Defense Education Act - science education priority
John Kenneth Galbraith, The Affluent Society - secular prosperity

1960.description: John F. Kennedy's Catholic candidacy tests religious tolerance. The contraceptive pill approved. Vatican II announced. The transformations of the 1960s begin. Religious authority will face unprecedented challenge.
key_manifestations: John F. Kennedy elected first Catholic president - separates faith from office
FDA approves oral contraceptive pill - sexual revolution begins
Vatican II announced by Pope John XXIII
Sit-in movement begins - secular civil rights activism

1962.description: Engel v. Vitale removes prayer from US public schools. Vatican II opens, Church engages modernity. Thomas Kuhn's Structure of Scientific Revolutions transforms philosophy of science. Secular knowledge's authority confirmed.
key_manifestations: Engel v. Vitale (1962) - school prayer unconstitutional
Thomas Kuhn, The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
Cuban Missile Crisis - secular apocalypse fear

1964.description: Civil Rights Act passes through secular political process. Time magazine asks 'Is God Dead?' (1966 forthcoming). Harvey Cox's The Secular City celebrates urban secularity. Religion retreats to private sphere.
key_manifestations: Civil Rights Act of 1964 - secular law achieves justice
Free Speech Movement at Berkeley - secular activism
Vatican II continues - Lumen Gentium, Unitatis Redintegratio
Herbert Marcuse, One-Dimensional Man - secular critique of modernity

1966.description: Time's 'Is God Dead?' cover crystallizes cultural shift. Death-of-God theology (Altizer, Hamilton) emerges. Vatican II concludes. Sexual revolution accelerates. Traditional religion loses authority over personal life.
key_manifestations: Thomas J.J. Altizer and William Hamilton, Radical Theology and the Death of God (1966)
Vatican II concludes with Gaudium et Spes
John Lennon: 'We're more popular than Jesus' controversy

1968.description: Humanae Vitae (contraception ban) widely rejected by Catholics. MLK and RFK assassinated. Prague Spring crushed. Countercultural spirituality emerges, bypassing institutional religion. Authority of all kinds questioned.
key_manifestations: Pope Paul VI, Humanae Vitae (1968) - massively rejected by laity
Martin Luther King Jr. assassinated - civil religion's martyr
2001: A Space Odyssey - cosmic awe without God
Peter Berger, The Sacred Canopy - sociology explains religion's plausibility

1970.description: Earth Day inaugurates secular environmentalism as spiritual cause. Religious vocations plummet. Mainline Protestantism's long decline accelerates. Hal Lindsey's Late Great Planet Earth shows religion surviving as apocalypticism.
key_manifestations: First Earth Day (1970) - secular environmental spirituality
Hal Lindsey, The Late Great Planet Earth - apocalyptic Christianity
Religious vocations collapse across Western Christianity

1972.description: Watergate scandal begins, secular political crisis. Club of Rome's Limits to Growth offers scientific apocalypse. Roe v. Wade (1973 forthcoming) will secularize reproductive decisions. Religion marginalized from public sphere.
key_manifestations: Club of Rome, The Limits to Growth (1972) - scientific apocalypticism
Gloria Steinem founds Ms. Magazine - secular feminism

1974.description: Nixon resigns in secular disgrace. Evangelical Christianity regroups globally with Lausanne Covenant. Charismatic renewal spreads. Religion adapts to secular age through experience-centered approaches.
key_manifestations: Robert Nozick, Anarchy, State, and Utopia - secular libertarianism

1976.description: Newsweek declares 'Year of the Evangelical.' Jimmy Carter elected as born-again Christian. Richard Dawkins publishes The Selfish Gene. Religion resurges politically while scientific worldview deepens culturally.
key_manifestations: Richard Dawkins, The Selfish Gene - gene-centered evolution
Apple Computer founded - technology as secular salvation

1978.description: John Paul II elected, begins revitalization of Catholic Church. Iranian Revolution demonstrates religion's political power globally. Jonestown massacre warns of religion's dark potential. Religion neither dead nor dominant.
key_manifestations: Iranian Revolution begins - political Islam resurges
Jonestown mass suicide - religion's destructive potential
First test-tube baby - science's power over life

1980.description: Moral Majority launches political activism. Reagan elected with evangelical support. John Lennon murdered. Religion returns to American politics forcefully. Yet this is culture war, not reenchantment - transcendence instrumentalized for politics.
key_manifestations: Ronald Reagan elected with evangelical support
John Lennon murdered - secular saint martyred
CNN launches - 24-hour secular news cycle begins

1982.description: Religious right consolidates political influence. John Paul II travels globally, reasserts Catholic identity. AIDS crisis begins, initially moralized religiously. Charles Taylor begins work toward A Secular Age.
key_manifestations: Equal Rights Amendment fails - religious opposition significant
John Paul II visits Britain - first papal visit since Reformation
Alasdair MacIntyre, After Virtue - moral philosophy post-God

1984.description: Culture wars intensify around abortion, school prayer. Carl Sagan's Cosmos reaches millions with scientific worldview. Joseph Ratzinger leads Vatican doctrinal enforcement. Religion fights defensive battles.
key_manifestations: Joseph Ratzinger's Congregation for Doctrine enforces orthodoxy
Carl Sagan, Cosmos television series (1980) reaches mass audience
Apple Macintosh '1984' ad - technology liberates from conformity

1986.description: Televangelist scandals (Jim Bakker, Jimmy Swaggart forthcoming) damage evangelical credibility. Challenger disaster mourned in secular rituals. Chernobyl reveals technological civilization's risks. Transcendence remains elusive.
key_manifestations: Jim Bakker scandal begins evangelical credibility crisis
Pope John Paul II at Assisi interfaith meeting

1988.description: Jimmy Swaggart scandal completes televangelist disgrace. Stephen Hawking's Brief History of Time bestseller. Pat Robertson's presidential campaign fails. Religion's political ambitions checked, scientific worldview popularized.
key_manifestations: Jimmy Swaggart scandal and tearful confession (1988)
Stephen Hawking, A Brief History of Time (1988) - cosmology for masses
The Last Temptation of Christ controversy - art vs. religion

1990.description: Cold War ends, removing 'godless communism' as religious rallying point. Soviet bloc churches freed but secularized populations emerge. American 'nones' category begins measurable growth. Globalization accelerates secular homogenization.
key_manifestations: Fall of Berlin Wall (1989) - end of ideological confrontation
Eastern European churches freed but populations deeply secularized
Human Genome Project launched - genetic reductionism
World Wide Web invented at CERN - information's secular temple

1992.description: Culture wars over family values. Francis Fukuyama's 'End of History' proclaims liberal democratic triumph. Vatican releases new catechism. Religion survives as subculture, not dominant framework.
key_manifestations: Culture wars: Murphy Brown controversy over family values
Francis Fukuyama, The End of History and the Last Man - secular liberalism triumphant
Catechism of the Catholic Church published
Earth Summit in Rio - secular global environmentalism

1994.description: Religious conflicts in former Yugoslavia, Rwanda show religion's continued power for violence. Promise Keepers movement among American men. Religion survives through identity politics, not recovered transcendence.
key_manifestations: Rwandan genocide - ethnic and religious violence intertwined
Evangelicals and Catholics Together document - political alliance
Promise Keepers rallies for men - evangelical identity movement

1996.description: 'Spiritual but not religious' category grows. Carl Sagan dies, secular prophet mourned. Dolly the sheep cloned. Religion increasingly personal choice, not social inheritance. Transcendence privatized.
key_manifestations: Carl Sagan dies (1996) - secular prophet mourned
Dolly the sheep cloned - human power over life's creation
Samuel Huntington, Clash of Civilizations - religion as geopolitical category

1998.description: Approaching millennium generates secular Y2K anxiety more than religious apocalypticism. John Paul II aging, Catholic Church's renewal fading. Internet transforms information access, further decentralizing authority.
key_manifestations: Y2K anxiety - secular technological apocalypse fear
Clinton impeachment - morality debates without religious resolution
Titanic film - secular myth of hubris and fate

2000.description: New millennium arrives with muted religious significance. Human genome sequenced. Dot-com bubble shows technology's quasi-religious faith. 'Spiritual but not religious' continues growth among young.
key_manifestations: Human genome draft completed - 'book of life' decoded
Bush v. Gore - secular law decides election

2002.description: Catholic clergy sex abuse scandal explodes in Boston. Post-9/11 religious rhetoric fades. Atheism becomes publishable position. Institutional religion's moral authority collapses under hypocrisy revelations.
key_manifestations: Boston Globe exposes Catholic clergy sex abuse (2002)
Cardinal Bernard Law resigns in disgrace
Richard Dawkins increasingly public as atheist voice
Daniel Dennett, Breaking the Spell research begins

2004.description: Evangelical voters help re-elect George W. Bush. Same-sex marriage becomes political issue. Sam Harris's End of Faith launches New Atheism. Religion politically mobilized but transcendence further evacuated.
key_manifestations: Sam Harris, The End of Faith (2004) - New Atheism begins

2006.description: New Atheism peaks with Dawkins's The God Delusion, Dennett's Breaking the Spell. Daniel Dennett and Richard Dawkins become public intellectuals. 'Nones' category grows rapidly among millennials.
key_manifestations: Richard Dawkins, The God Delusion (2006) - bestseller
Daniel Dennett, Breaking the Spell: Religion as a Natural Phenomenon
Pope Benedict XVI's Regensburg lecture controversy
An Inconvenient Truth - secular environmentalism as cause

2008.description: Christopher Hitchens's God Is Not Great joins New Atheist canon. Financial crisis interpreted through economic, not theological, frameworks. Obama elected, less overt religiosity than predecessors. Secularization accelerates.
key_manifestations: Christopher Hitchens, God Is Not Great (2007) - New Atheism continues
Global financial crisis - secular economic apocalypse
Large Hadron Collider activates - physics seeks origins

2010.description: 'Nones' reach 15-20% of American population. Social media transforms religious community and authority. Stephen Hawking declares philosophy dead. Charles Taylor's A Secular Age (2007) provides definitive analysis.
key_manifestations: Charles Taylor's A Secular Age (2007) widely discussed
Stephen Hawking and Leonard Mlodinow, The Grand Design - 'philosophy is dead'
iPad launched - technology as daily liturgy

2012.description: Pew Research documents dramatic 'nones' rise. Higgs boson discovered, 'God particle' reveals nature's structure. Obama endorses same-sex marriage. Religious arguments lose persuasive force in public sphere.
key_manifestations: Pew Research: 'Nones' at 20% of American adults
Higgs boson confirmed at CERN - scientific understanding deepens
Obama endorses same-sex marriage - religious opposition marginalized
Christopher Hitchens dies (2011) - New Atheist icon mourned

2014.description: Pope Francis generates interest without reversing trends. ISIS demonstrates religion's capacity for violence. Same-sex marriage advances. Millennials least religious generation in American history.
key_manifestations: Pope Francis's popularity without reversing secularization
ISIS declares caliphate - religious violence in modern form
Same-sex marriage spreads across US states
Cosmos reboot with Neil deGrasse Tyson - scientific worldview

2016.description: Evangelical support for Trump reveals religion instrumentalized for politics, not transcendence. Mother Teresa canonized. Gene editing (CRISPR) advances. Religion survives as identity marker, not cosmic orientation.
key_manifestations: White evangelical support for Donald Trump (81%)
Mother Teresa canonized by Pope Francis
CRISPR gene editing advances - human redesign possible
Brexit and Trump - nationalism with religious undertones

2018.description: Pennsylvania grand jury exposes decades of Catholic abuse. #MeToo reveals religious institutions' complicity. Stephen Hawking dies. 'Nones' continue rapid growth. Transcendence evacuated, instrumental reason remains.
key_manifestations: Pennsylvania grand jury report on Catholic abuse - 300 priests, 1000 victims
Stephen Hawking dies (2018) - secular prophet mourned globally
Jordan Peterson's religious-adjacent philosophy gains following

2020.description: COVID-19 pandemic closes churches, accelerates digital transformation. Science-religion tension over public health measures. George Floyd protests show secular moral mobilization. Disenchantment reaches provisional completion - transcendence evacuated, instrumental reason governs, beauty loses 'own verification.'
key_manifestations: George Floyd protests - secular moral mobilization

13_attention_economy_capture.name: Attention Economy Capture
13_attention_economy_capture.description: The progressive colonization of human consciousness by commercial media - from newspapers to radio to television to social media, each wave more effective at harvesting attention. This cluster tracks how 'engagement' displaced beauty as the criterion for content, how algorithms optimizing for attention eroded aesthetic judgment, and how the 'endless slop' the essay laments became economically inevitable. The shift from beauty bearing 'its own verification' to content valued solely by its capacity to capture eyeballs and generate clicks.

1880.description: Δw emerges minimally as Joseph Pulitzer acquires the New York World and pioneers sensationalism; attention-capture begins displacing the older penny press model of civic information, with headlines designed to grab rather than inform, initiating the commercial logic that would eventually exile beauty from mass media.
key_manifestations: Joseph Pulitzer's acquisition of New York World (1883)
Growth of newsboys and street hawking culture

1882.description: Δw advances as the New York World's circulation explodes from 15,000 to 100,000 under Pulitzer's sensationalist methods; the market proves that attention-grabbing content generates profit regardless of aesthetic merit, establishing the economic logic that would govern all subsequent media.
key_manifestations: New York World circulation surge under Pulitzer
Introduction of sports pages and women's sections
Expansion of crime reporting with lurid detail

1884.description: Δw increases as the Cleveland-Blaine election becomes the first presidential campaign dominated by newspaper scandal-mongering; 'Ma, Ma, Where's My Pa?' headlines demonstrate that political coverage optimized for attention rather than civic education sells papers, establishing the template for attention-driven political media.
key_manifestations: Maria Halpin scandal coverage in Grover Cleveland campaign
'Ma, Ma, Where's My Pa?' newspaper headlines
Blaine's 'Rum, Romanism, and Rebellion' media firestorm

1886.description: Δw expands as Pulitzer's World fundraises for the Statue of Liberty pedestal through participatory journalism; this innovative attention-capture technique—making readers feel invested—demonstrates that engagement metrics matter more than aesthetic contemplation, previewing social media's participatory logic.
key_manifestations: Pulitzer's Statue of Liberty pedestal fundraising campaign
New York World printing donor names (proto-social recognition)
Growth of reader participation features in newspapers

1888.description: Δw accelerates as Nellie Bly feigns insanity to expose asylum conditions for the World; stunt journalism proves that manufactured spectacle captures attention more effectively than traditional reporting, establishing the principle that creating events matters more than beautifully describing existing ones.
key_manifestations: Nellie Bly's 'Ten Days in a Mad-House' exposé

1890.description: Δw intensifies as Nellie Bly's 72-day around-the-world race becomes the first global media spectacle; newspapers discover that manufactured events with daily updates create sustained attention capture, prefiguring serialized content and real-time engagement metrics.
key_manifestations: Daily progress updates as proto-engagement content

1892.description: Δw grows as dedicated sports sections expand across American newspapers; the emotional engagement of athletic competition provides reliable attention capture regardless of aesthetic content, demonstrating that visceral excitement trumps beautiful writing.

1894.description: Δw advances as color printing enables the first newspaper comic strips; visual attention-capture through bright colors and simple narratives proves more engaging than text-heavy content, beginning the visual turn that would culminate in video dominance.
key_manifestations: Introduction of color printing in Sunday supplements

1896.description: Δw surges as Hearst acquires the New York Journal and the Yellow Kid comic strip, launching the Pulitzer-Hearst circulation war; 'yellow journalism' becomes the first named attention-capture ideology, explicitly prioritizing sensation over accuracy or beauty.
key_manifestations: William Randolph Hearst acquires New York Journal
R.F. Outcault's 'Yellow Kid' comic strip wars

1898.description: Δw spikes dramatically as yellow journalism arguably manufactures the Spanish-American War; 'You furnish the pictures, I'll furnish the war' (attributed to Hearst) epitomizes attention-capture's power to shape reality itself, demonstrating that engagement metrics can override truth, beauty, and human welfare.
key_manifestations: USS Maine explosion coverage and 'Remember the Maine!'
Hearst's alleged telegram: 'You furnish the pictures...'

1900.description: Δw continues as major newspapers achieve million-copy circulations; the attention economy reaches industrial scale, with content production optimized for maximum engagement rather than aesthetic merit, creating the template for all subsequent mass media.
key_manifestations: New York Journal and World exceed one million circulation

1902.description: Δw advances as McClure's Magazine pioneers muckraking journalism; while exposing genuine corruption, the muckraking format demonstrates that outrage captures attention more reliably than beauty, establishing moral indignation as an engagement metric.
key_manifestations: Ida Tarbell begins Standard Oil investigation

1904.description: Δw grows as Ida Tarbell's 'History of the Standard Oil Company' serialization proves that sustained investigative content maintains reader attention; while genuinely important, the success establishes that serialized outrage is an optimal engagement format.
key_manifestations: Ida Tarbell's 'History of Standard Oil' serialization completion

1906.description: Δw continues as Theodore Roosevelt coins 'muckraker' in criticism of sensationalist journalism; the tension between attention-capture and responsible discourse enters political debate, though Roosevelt himself mastered attention-capture through his 'bully pulpit.'
key_manifestations: Upton Sinclair's 'The Jungle' and its sensationalist impact

1908.description: Δw accelerates as nickelodeons proliferate across America; moving pictures prove exponentially more effective at capturing attention than static text, initiating the shift toward visual media that would culminate in video's dominance over written beauty.
key_manifestations: Nickelodeon theater explosion across urban America
Edison's Motion Picture Patents Company formation

1910.description: Δw grows as the tabloid newspaper format develops in Britain and begins influencing American journalism; the smaller format with larger headlines and more photographs represents attention-capture optimized for urban commuters, sacrificing depth for grabbing glances.
key_manifestations: Daily Mirror's tabloid success in Britain

1912.description: Δw spikes as the Titanic disaster creates the first modern media frenzy with wireless-enabled real-time coverage; the combination of tragedy, celebrity, and technology demonstrates that catastrophe captures attention with unprecedented intensity, establishing disaster as premium content.
key_manifestations: Titanic sinking coverage and misinformation spread
Newspaper extra editions and circulation spikes

1914.description: Δw increases as World War I propaganda demonstrates attention-capture's power on a national scale; governments discover that emotionally manipulative content captures and directs mass attention more effectively than rational argument, industrializing the displacement of aesthetic judgment by engagement.

1916.description: Δw advances as the Committee on Public Information (Creel Committee) prepares for American entry into WWI; Edward Bernays and other pioneers develop systematic attention-capture techniques that will become advertising and public relations, explicitly subordinating truth to engagement.

1918.description: Δw grows as WWI propaganda proves its effectiveness in mobilizing American public opinion; the success validates attention-capture as a governable technology, with practitioners like Bernays preparing to apply wartime techniques to commercial advertising.
key_manifestations: Four Minute Men speech program (75,000 speakers)

1920.description: Δw surges as KDKA Pittsburgh broadcasts the first commercial radio programs; a new attention-capture technology emerges that can enter homes directly, bypassing the effort of reading and establishing the passive consumption model that would dominate subsequent media.

1922.description: Δw increases as WEAF New York broadcasts the first paid radio advertisement; the advertising-supported media model is born, establishing that content exists to deliver audience attention to advertisers, making engagement the explicit economic purpose of media.
key_manifestations: WEAF broadcasts first paid radio advertisement (Queensboro Corporation)

1924.description: Δw advances as New York's tabloid newspaper wars intensify; the Daily News, Daily Mirror, and Evening Graphic compete in sensationalism, with the Graphic pioneering 'composograph' fake photographs—early deepfakes demonstrating that attention-capture will sacrifice truth for engagement.
key_manifestations: New York Daily News circulation dominance

1926.description: Δw grows as NBC forms the first national radio network; nationwide simultaneous broadcasting enables attention-capture at unprecedented scale, creating the mass audience that advertisers crave and beginning the centralization of attention that would reach its apex in network television.
key_manifestations: NBC (National Broadcasting Company) formation by RCA

1928.description: Δw advances as Edward Bernays publishes 'Propaganda,' codifying attention-capture techniques for commercial use; the book explicitly argues for manipulating public consciousness, establishing the theoretical framework for advertising's colonization of attention.

1930.description: Δw grows as radio becomes the dominant mass medium during the Depression; families gather around sets for sponsored entertainment, establishing the template of commercial content capturing household attention that television would perfect.
key_manifestations: Amos 'n' Andy peak popularity (40 million listeners)
Radio as primary entertainment medium during Depression

1932.description: Δw continues as FDR's radio mastery demonstrates that attention-capture determines political success; the 'fireside chat' format proves that intimate, engaging communication trumps policy substance, establishing the media performance requirements that would shape all subsequent politics.
key_manifestations: Rise of radio as political medium
Decline of print journalism political influence

1934.description: Δw advances as FDR's fireside chats perfect the intimate broadcast address; the format demonstrates that personal emotional connection captures attention more effectively than formal political discourse, establishing parasocial relationship as an engagement technique.
key_manifestations: Radio as primary news source surpassing newspapers

1936.description: Δw grows as the Cooperative Analysis of Broadcasting develops systematic radio ratings; the scientific measurement of audience attention creates the metrics that will drive all subsequent media, making engagement quantifiable and thus manageable.
key_manifestations: Cooperative Analysis of Broadcasting (CAB) ratings expansion

1938.description: Δw surges as Orson Welles's 'War of the Worlds' broadcast causes panic; the event demonstrates radio's terrifying power to capture and manipulate attention, showing that engagement can override critical thinking—a preview of social media's capacity to spread viral misinformation.
key_manifestations: Orson Welles's 'War of the Worlds' broadcast panic
Debate over broadcasting's power and responsibility

1940.description: Δw advances as World War II demonstrates attention-capture's strategic importance; Edward R. Murrow's London broadcasts prove that compelling content can shape public opinion across oceans, while war propaganda techniques reach new sophistication.
key_manifestations: Edward R. Murrow's 'This Is London' broadcasts
War news dominance of radio programming

1942.description: Δw grows as the Office of War Information coordinates American propaganda; attention-capture becomes national security infrastructure, with Hollywood, radio, and print coordinated to maintain public engagement with the war effort, proving media's power to shape consciousness.
key_manifestations: Why We Fight film series (Frank Capra)

1944.description: Δw advances as television development continues during wartime, promising post-war attention-capture of unprecedented power; the combination of visual and audio media will prove even more engaging than radio, preparing to colonize domestic space more completely.
key_manifestations: First television sets in wealthy homes

1946.description: Δw surges as television broadcasting expands post-war; the new medium combines radio's intimacy with visual engagement, proving immediately that moving pictures capture attention more completely than any previous technology, beginning television's colonization of domestic life.

1948.description: Δw grows as the 1948 political conventions are televised; the merger of politics and television entertainment begins, establishing that political success requires mastering attention-capture through the visual medium, regardless of policy substance or rhetorical beauty.
key_manifestations: Television as status symbol in American homes

1950.description: Δw increases as Nielsen television ratings become the currency of the attention economy; programming decisions are now made explicitly based on engagement metrics rather than quality, aesthetics, or public benefit—the logic that would produce 'endless slop.'
key_manifestations: Advertiser control over content via ratings pressure

1952.description: Δw surges as Nixon's 'Checkers' speech demonstrates television's power to bypass traditional media gatekeepers through direct emotional appeal; the theatrical performance capturing 60 million viewers proves that televisual engagement trumps substantive argument.
key_manifestations: Television as tool for political survival
I Love Lucy premiere and dominance

1954.description: Δw advances as television penetration exceeds 50% of American households; the attention-capture device is now the center of domestic life, restructuring family time around programming schedules and establishing the model of passive evening consumption.
key_manifestations: TV penetration exceeds 50% of US households
Tonight Show premiere with Steve Allen

1956.description: Δw grows as television advertising reaches sophistication; Vance Packard will soon expose the 'hidden persuaders' using psychological manipulation to capture attention and drive consumption, demonstrating the systematic colonization of consciousness by commercial interests.

1958.description: Δw continues despite the quiz show scandals exposing that engagement-optimized content is manufactured rather than authentic; 'Twenty-One' and other shows were rigged for maximum drama, demonstrating that attention-capture logic corrupts content regardless of audience trust.

1960.description: Δw surges as the Nixon-Kennedy debates demonstrate that television appearance determines political success; those who watched on TV favored Kennedy while radio listeners favored Nixon, proving that visual engagement matters more than argumentative substance or rhetorical beauty.

1962.description: Δw advances despite FCC Chairman Newton Minow's 'vast wasteland' condemnation of television; his critique that engagement-optimized programming produces cultural poverty rather than beauty goes unheeded as ratings continue to drive content decisions.

1964.description: Δw grows as the 'Daisy' ad demonstrates that fear captures attention more effectively than hope; the Johnson campaign's nuclear-apocalypse advertisement establishes negative emotional manipulation as the most effective attention-capture technique in political media.

1966.description: Δw advances as Vietnam becomes the first 'living room war'; nightly television coverage brings combat footage into homes, demonstrating that violence and conflict capture attention with exceptional effectiveness, establishing war as premium engagement content.
key_manifestations: Morley Safer's 'Burning of Cam Ne' report

1968.description: Δw surges as 1968's televised assassinations, riots, and convention chaos demonstrate television's power to shape historical consciousness; the medium's appetite for dramatic footage incentivizes conflict, as attention-capture logic begins shaping the events it covers.

1970.description: Δw continues as the FCC's Prime Time Access Rule attempts to diversify programming but instead produces syndicated game shows and tabloid content; regulatory intervention cannot overcome the economic logic that attention-capture produces lower-quality content.
key_manifestations: Game show and tabloid content proliferation

1972.description: Δw grows as Nixon's campaign demonstrates sophisticated media manipulation techniques; 'The Selling of the President' model explicitly treats voters as consumers of attention-capture content, with political image management superseding substantive policy debate.
key_manifestations: Joe McGinniss's 'The Selling of the President'

1974.description: Δw advances as Watergate hearings become must-watch television drama; the congressional investigation proves that political scandal captures attention with exceptional effectiveness, establishing the investigative-spectacle format that will dominate subsequent political coverage.

1976.description: Δw continues as Barbara Walters becomes the first million-dollar news anchor; the salary milestone demonstrates that news has become entertainment, with anchors valued for their attention-capture abilities rather than journalistic excellence or aesthetic presentation.

1978.description: Δw grows as local news 'happy talk' and tabloid formats spread; consultants like Frank Magid advise stations to prioritize entertainment over information, explicitly optimizing for engagement metrics rather than journalistic quality or civic benefit.

1980.description: Δw surges as CNN launches 24-hour news coverage; the endless news cycle creates insatiable demand for attention-capturing content, accelerating the transformation of news into entertainment and establishing the constant-engagement model that social media will perfect.

1982.description: Δw increases as MTV launches, establishing rapid-cut visual editing as the aesthetic of attention-capture; music videos train audiences to expect constant visual stimulation, shortening attention spans and establishing the visual grammar that will dominate digital media.
key_manifestations: Music video as art form/advertisement hybrid

1984.description: Δw grows as Apple's '1984' Super Bowl commercial transforms advertising into event television; the irony of using Orwellian imagery to promote a future attention-capture technology is lost as advertising becomes content people actively seek to watch.
key_manifestations: Super Bowl advertising as cultural event

1986.description: Δw advances as daytime talk shows pioneer confessional content; Oprah, Donahue, and imitators discover that personal revelation and emotional drama capture attention more effectively than educational content, establishing the vulnerability-as-engagement model.

1988.description: Δw grows as the average political sound bite shrinks to under 10 seconds; television's attention-capture logic compresses political discourse to maximum-engagement fragments, eliminating the space for nuanced argument or rhetorical beauty.
key_manifestations: Sound bite length compression in campaigns
Willie Horton ad and attack advertising

1990.description: Δw surges as the Gulf War becomes CNN's breakthrough; real-time war coverage as television spectacle demonstrates that conflict is the ultimate attention-capture content, establishing 24-hour crisis coverage as the cable news model.

1992.description: Δw increases as MTV's 'The Real World' invents reality television; the format discovers that manufactured authenticity captures attention more effectively and cheaply than scripted content, beginning the shift toward the algorithmic slop the essay laments.

1994.description: Δw spikes as the O.J. Simpson case becomes the first total-immersion media spectacle; the slow-speed chase watched by 95 million viewers demonstrates that live drama captures attention with unprecedented intensity, prefiguring social media's real-time engagement.
key_manifestations: O.J. Simpson Bronco chase (95 million viewers)

1996.description: Δw grows as Fox News launches with explicit partisan framing; the network discovers that tribal identity captures attention more reliably than objective journalism, establishing the outrage-engagement model that will define social media discourse.

1998.description: Δw advances as the Drudge Report breaks the Lewinsky scandal; the website demonstrates that internet publishing can capture attention faster than traditional media, establishing the speed-over-accuracy model that will define digital journalism.

2000.description: Δw grows as 'Survivor' and 'Big Brother' launch the reality television boom; these shows perfect the cheap-to-produce, high-engagement format, demonstrating that manufactured drama captures attention without requiring aesthetic quality or creative effort.

2002.description: Δw increases as 'American Idol' demonstrates that audience participation enhances engagement; voting creates investment in outcomes, previewing social media's discovery that participation captures attention more effectively than passive consumption.
key_manifestations: American Idol premiere and ratings dominance

2004.description: Δw surges as Facebook launches at Harvard; the platform will pioneer algorithmic attention-capture, using social connections and psychological manipulation to maximize engagement, beginning the transformation of human relationships into attention-harvesting infrastructure.

2006.description: Δw spikes as YouTube (acquired by Google) and Twitter launch; user-generated video and microblogging create infinite content supply competing for attention, while algorithmic recommendation begins optimizing for engagement over quality or beauty.

2008.description: Δw grows as Obama's campaign masters social media attention-capture; the success demonstrates that political viability now requires algorithmic optimization for engagement, completing the transformation of politics from deliberation to performance.

2010.description: Δw surges as smartphone penetration enables constant attention-capture; the device in every pocket means engagement opportunities are now unlimited, with push notifications ensuring that attention can be harvested at any moment of any day.
key_manifestations: App economy and push notification culture

2012.description: Δw accelerates as Facebook and Twitter shift to algorithmic feeds; human curation is replaced by engagement-optimization algorithms, ensuring that content is ranked solely by its capacity to capture attention regardless of truth, beauty, or human welfare.

2014.description: Δw grows as clickbait reaches industrial scale; headlines are A/B tested and optimized purely for clicks, with content quality irrelevant to success. 'You won't believe what happens next' becomes the dominant aesthetic, explicitly designed to override judgment.
key_manifestations: Upworthy, ViralNova, and clickbait farm proliferation
Facebook algorithm rewards engagement over quality

2016.description: Δw spikes as algorithms are revealed to radicalize users; YouTube's recommendation engine and Facebook's News Feed optimize for engagement by promoting extreme content, demonstrating that attention-capture logic produces increasingly toxic outcomes.
key_manifestations: Facebook fake news proliferation in election

2018.description: Δw continues despite growing criticism of attention-capture's harms; 'The Social Dilemma' consciousness emerges, with former tech employees warning of addictive design, yet platforms continue optimizing for engagement as their economic logic remains unchanged.
key_manifestations: Tristan Harris's Center for Humane Technology

2020.description: Δw reaches its apex as TikTok's algorithm achieves unprecedented attention-capture efficiency; the For You Page creates infinite personalized content streams optimizing for dopamine response, completing the colonization of consciousness that began with yellow journalism and producing the 'endless slop' of algorithmically-generated, engagement-optimized content that has displaced beauty entirely as a criterion for cultural value.
key_manifestations: Short-form video as dominant content format

14_frontier_mythology.name: Frontier Mythology and Edge-of-World Consciousness
14_frontier_mythology.description: The American narrative of the frontier as site of renewal, transformation, and new beginning - from Frederick Jackson Turner's frontier thesis through the Space Age to Silicon Valley's 'final frontier.' The essay opens with the Bay Area as 'edge of the known world' where 'the Gods seem to have lavished the land with majestic, inexhaustible beauty' and where 'creation could begin again, this time under human authorship.' This cluster tracks how frontier mythology shaped American self-understanding and how it migrated from geographic to technological to digital frontiers.

1880.description: Baseline Δw=0.0 establishes frontier consciousness at peak geographical expansion, with transcontinental railroad completed and Western territories rapidly filling, the 1880 Census showing frontier line still visible but contracting.
key_manifestations: Census Bureau frontier line mapping of 1880
Helen Hunt Jackson's early Western romanticism
Denver & Rio Grande Railway expansion into Colorado Rockies
Sitting Bull's surrender marking end of Plains resistance

1882.description: Δw=+0.01 reflects slight intensification as frontier anxiety begins emerging through immigration restriction (Chinese Exclusion Act) attempting to preserve frontier opportunity for 'authentic' Americans.
key_manifestations: Jesse James death romanticizes outlaw frontier
Buffalo Bill Cody's Wild West show begins development
Standard Oil Trust consolidation of Western resources

1884.description: Δw=+0.03 shows frontier mythology crystallizing as Theodore Roosevelt retreats to Dakota Badlands after personal tragedy, beginning his transformation into frontier archetype and cowboy philosopher.
key_manifestations: Theodore Roosevelt's Elkhorn Ranch in Dakota Territory
Roosevelt's 'Hunting Trips of a Ranchman' composition begins
Mark Twain's 'Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' frontier escape
Cattle boom reaches peak across Great Plains

1886.description: Δw=+0.04 registers ecological crisis threatening frontier myth as Great Die-Up of 1886-87 devastates cattle industry, revealing frontier not as inexhaustible but as fragile ecosystem.
key_manifestations: Great Die-Up cattle disaster of winter 1886-87
Statue of Liberty dedication redirecting frontier promise to immigrants
American Federation of Labor founding signals industrial frontier

1888.description: Δw=+0.06 marks intensifying nostalgia as frontier appears to be closing, with Oklahoma land rush preparations and Frederick Jackson Turner beginning his graduate studies at Johns Hopkins.
key_manifestations: Turner begins graduate work under Herbert Baxter Adams
Theodore Roosevelt's 'Ranch Life and the Hunting Trail'
George Eastman's Kodak camera democratizes frontier documentation
Edward Curtis begins photographing Native Americans

1890.description: Δw=+0.20 represents major inflection as 1890 Census officially declares frontier line closed, creating the very crisis Turner will theorize—the end of the safety valve that defined American character and democracy.
key_manifestations: Wounded Knee Massacre marks violent end of Indian frontier
Ghost Dance movement as Native response to frontier closure
Jacob Riis 'How the Other Half Lives' shows urban anti-frontier

1892.description: Δw=+0.22 shows frontier anxiety channeling into populist politics and labor unrest (Homestead Strike), as Americans grapple with what happens when the escape valve closes and conflicts must be faced.
key_manifestations: Sierra Club founded by John Muir to preserve frontier wilderness
Ellis Island opens as new immigrant frontier gateway

1893.description: Δw=+0.33 marks the theoretical crystallization as Turner delivers 'The Significance of the Frontier in American History' at the Chicago World's Fair, arguing frontier experience created American democracy, individualism, and national character.
key_manifestations: Frederick Jackson Turner's Frontier Thesis at AHA Chicago meeting
Katharine Lee Bates writes 'America the Beautiful' at Pikes Peak

1894.description: Δw=+0.31 reflects frontier thesis dissemination as Turner's ideas begin circulating among historians, while Pullman Strike reveals industrial conflicts that closed frontier cannot absorb.
key_manifestations: Turner appointed professor at University of Wisconsin
Immigration restriction debates intensify in Congress

1896.description: Δw=+0.29 shows frontier mythology politicized as William Jennings Bryan's 'Cross of Gold' speech channels agrarian frontier values against Eastern industrial interests, losing but defining populist frontier nostalgia.
key_manifestations: William Jennings Bryan's Cross of Gold speech
Klondike Gold Rush begins redirecting frontier to Alaska
Plessy v. Ferguson forecloses racial frontier of equality
William McKinley's 'full dinner pail' industrial promise

1898.description: Δw=+0.27 reflects frontier's imperial turn as Spanish-American War projects frontier mythology overseas—Philippines, Cuba, Puerto Rico become new frontiers for American expansion and 'civilization.'
key_manifestations: Theodore Roosevelt's Rough Riders as frontier heroes

1900.description: Δw=+0.24 shows frontier transformed into imperial ideology as Philippine-American War continues, Turner's thesis becomes standard interpretation, and 'strenuous life' philosophy treats imperialism as frontier substitute.
key_manifestations: L. Frank Baum's 'The Wizard of Oz' Kansas frontier mythology
Galveston hurricane devastates Texas frontier port

1902.description: Δw=+0.22 reflects frontier mythology entering conservation phase as Roosevelt becomes president and Newlands Reclamation Act begins transforming Western frontier through federal irrigation projects.
key_manifestations: Newlands Reclamation Act for Western irrigation
Owen Wister's 'The Virginian' creates cowboy novel genre
Anthracite Coal Strike tests industrial frontier
Roosevelt's conservation correspondence with John Muir

1904.description: Δw=+0.20 shows frontier projected globally through Roosevelt Corollary to Monroe Doctrine, treating Western Hemisphere as American frontier, while St. Louis World's Fair celebrates Louisiana Purchase expansion.
key_manifestations: Louisiana Purchase Exposition in St. Louis
Roosevelt's landslide election on frontier-inflected platform

1906.description: Δw=+0.21 marks San Francisco earthquake as frontier city destruction, followed by rapid rebuilding embodying frontier spirit of renewal, while Antiquities Act begins preserving frontier landscapes as national monuments.
key_manifestations: Antiquities Act passage enabling monument preservation
Upton Sinclair's 'The Jungle' exposes immigrant frontier
Devil's Tower first national monument designation

1908.description: Δw=+0.19 reflects frontier mythology stabilizing in conservation movement as Roosevelt creates national forests and Grand Canyon becomes national monument, preserving frontier wilderness for future Americans.
key_manifestations: Model T Ford begins democratizing mobility frontier
Robert Peary's Arctic expedition claims polar frontier

1910.description: Δw=+0.16 shows frontier mythology institutionalizing as Boy Scouts of America founded to instill frontier virtues in urban youth, while Glacier National Park preserves Northern frontier landscape.
key_manifestations: Boy Scouts of America founded by Ernest Thompson Seton
Mexican Revolution begins border frontier turbulence

1912.description: Δw=+0.14 reflects continental frontier officially closed as Arizona and New Mexico achieve statehood completing contiguous 48 states, while Titanic disaster symbolizes limits of technological frontier.
key_manifestations: Arizona and New Mexico statehood completing Lower 48
Titanic sinking exposes technological frontier limits
Woodrow Wilson's 'New Freedom' as social frontier

1914.description: Δw=+0.12 shows frontier redirecting as Panama Canal opens creating commercial frontier passage, while World War I begins revealing European lack of frontier safety valve for conflicts.
key_manifestations: Panama Canal opens to commercial traffic
World War I erupts in Europe
Charlie Chaplin's 'The Tramp' frontier wanderer archetype
Federal Reserve System creates financial frontier

1916.description: Δw=+0.13 marks National Park Service creation institutionalizing frontier preservation, while Pancho Villa raid and Pershing Expedition revive border frontier consciousness.
key_manifestations: Pancho Villa's Columbus raid and Pershing Expedition
Jeannette Rankin first woman in Congress from frontier Montana
Margaret Sanger opens birth control clinic as reproductive frontier

1918.description: Δw=+0.11 reflects WWI ending with Wilson's Fourteen Points projecting American frontier idealism globally—self-determination as international frontier principle, though League of Nations fails to pass.
key_manifestations: Spanish Flu pandemic closes social frontiers
Willa Cather's 'My Antonia' elegizes pioneer frontier

1920.description: Δw=+0.09 shows frontier mythology transforming as 1920 Census reveals majority urban population for first time, fundamentally shifting frontier from geographic to technological and cultural domains.
key_manifestations: Nineteenth Amendment as political frontier for women
First commercial radio broadcast KDKA Pittsburgh
Sinclair Lewis's 'Main Street' critiques small-town frontier

1922.description: Δw=+0.07 reflects frontier consciousness in media age as Western films proliferate, Lincoln Memorial dedication sacralizes frontier president, and Frederick Jackson Turner publishes 'The Frontier in American History.'
key_manifestations: Frederick Jackson Turner's 'The Frontier in American History' collection
Reader's Digest founded democratizing knowledge frontier
Tom Mix Western films at height of popularity

1924.description: Δw=+0.05 shows frontier mythology hardening into exclusion as Immigration Act of 1924 closes frontier to Southern and Eastern Europeans, attempting to preserve Anglo-Saxon frontier character.
key_manifestations: Immigration Act of 1924 national origins quotas
J. Edgar Hoover begins FBI as law enforcement frontier
Teapot Dome scandal corrupts Western resource frontier

1926.description: Δw=+0.04 reflects aviation emerging as new frontier as Air Commerce Act passes and Route 66 authorized, creating new mobility frontiers while Will Rogers embodies frontier humor.
key_manifestations: Air Commerce Act regulating aviation frontier
Ernest Hemingway's 'The Sun Also Rises' expatriate frontier
NBC Radio Network creates broadcast frontier

1928.description: Δw=+0.06 marks frontier mythology resurging as Herbert Hoover campaigns on 'rugged individualism' frontier values, while Disney's Steamboat Willie signals cultural frontier of animation.
key_manifestations: Amelia Earhart's transatlantic flight as aviation frontier
Boulder Canyon Project Act for Hoover Dam

1930.description: Δw=+0.02 shows frontier mythology colliding with Depression reality as frontier individualism fails to address mass unemployment, while Grant Wood's 'American Gothic' critiques rural frontier mythology.
key_manifestations: Planet Pluto discovered extending cosmic frontier

1932.description: Δw=-0.04 reflects frontier mythology's Depression crisis as FDR promises 'New Deal' collectivist frontier replacing rugged individualism, while Bonus Army march shows frontier veterans' desperation.
key_manifestations: Reconstruction Finance Corporation as government frontier
Empire State Building as vertical urban frontier

1934.description: Δw=-0.07 marks frontier mythology's ecological collapse as Dust Bowl devastates Great Plains, revealing frontier exploitation's environmental consequences while Taylor Grazing Act attempts to regulate.
key_manifestations: Taylor Grazing Act regulating public lands
Indian Reorganization Act partially reverses frontier dispossession

1936.description: Δw=-0.05 shows frontier mythology adapting as Hoover Dam completion demonstrates collective conquest of frontier through federal power, while 'Gone with the Wind' novel romanticizes Southern frontier loss.
key_manifestations: Hoover Dam completion on Colorado River
Margaret Mitchell's 'Gone with the Wind' publication
Rural Electrification Administration extends technological frontier
Jesse Owens challenges racial frontier at Berlin Olympics

1938.description: Δw=-0.03 reflects frontier mythology mediated through mass culture as 'Stagecoach' revives Western genre and Orson Welles's 'War of the Worlds' broadcast suggests extraterrestrial frontier anxieties.
key_manifestations: Orson Welles's 'War of the Worlds' broadcast panic
Fair Labor Standards Act as worker frontier
Superman debuts as frontier hero in new medium

1940.description: Δw=0.0 returns to baseline as WWII preparation redirects frontier energy toward arsenal of democracy, with peacetime draft and industrial mobilization creating new production frontiers.
key_manifestations: Woody Guthrie's 'This Land Is Your Land' folk frontier
First McDonald's in San Bernardino suburban frontier

1942.description: Δw=+0.02 shows frontier mythology militarized as Pacific Theater extends frontier to Asia, Manhattan Project begins atomic frontier, and Japanese American internment violates frontier promise.
key_manifestations: Manhattan Project begins at Los Alamos
Bataan Death March Pacific frontier tragedy
Casablanca film as wartime frontier romance

1944.description: Δw=+0.04 reflects postwar frontier planning as GI Bill promises education and housing frontiers for returning veterans, while D-Day liberates European frontier from fascism.
key_manifestations: Bretton Woods Conference creates economic frontier institutions
Vannevar Bush's 'Science: The Endless Frontier' report conception

1946.description: Δw=+0.06 marks nuclear and suburban frontiers emerging as Atomic Energy Commission forms, Levittown construction begins mass suburban frontier, and 'It's a Wonderful Life' celebrates small-town frontier values.
key_manifestations: Levittown construction begins on Long Island
ENIAC computer unveiled as computational frontier
Dr. Benjamin Spock's 'Baby and Child Care' parenting frontier

1948.description: Δw=+0.08 shows Cold War frontier crystallizing as Berlin Airlift defends Western frontier, Truman desegregates military opening racial frontier, and transistor invention signals electronic frontier.
key_manifestations: Alfred Kinsey's 'Sexual Behavior in the Human Male' research frontier
