1950.description: Δw=+0.10 reflects frontier anxiety in Korean War and McCarthyism as ideological frontier hardens against communism, while suburban frontier expands and television becomes new cultural frontier.
key_manifestations: Korean War begins as Asian frontier conflict
McCarthy's Wheeling speech on communist infiltration
Diners Club first credit card as consumer frontier
Peanuts comic strip debuts with frontier outsider Charlie Brown

1952.description: Δw=+0.12 shows frontier mythology in nuclear age as first hydrogen bomb test extends destructive frontier, while 'High Noon' Western allegorizes McCarthy era frontier courage.
key_manifestations: First hydrogen bomb test at Eniwetok Atoll
Ralph Ellison's 'Invisible Man' as racial frontier text

1954.description: Δw=+0.13 marks civil rights frontier opening as Brown v. Board ends legal segregation, while Disneyland planning brings frontier mythology to theme park and 'Shane' elegizes frontier violence.
key_manifestations: Brown v. Board of Education decision

1956.description: Δw=+0.15 reflects frontier mythology in interstate age as Federal Highway Act creates automobile frontier connecting nation, while Montgomery Bus Boycott advances civil rights frontier.
key_manifestations: Elvis Presley on Ed Sullivan as cultural frontier

1958.description: Δw=+0.20 marks space frontier emerging post-Sputnik as NASA created, Explorer 1 launched, and National Defense Education Act channels frontier anxiety into education, while Alaska approaches statehood.
key_manifestations: NASA established in response to Sputnik
Alaska statehood movement advances last territorial frontier

1960.description: Δw=+0.30 represents major transformation as JFK's 'New Frontier' explicitly revives Turner thesis for space age, promising moon mission and Peace Corps as new frontiers for American energy and idealism.
key_manifestations: John F. Kennedy's 'New Frontier' acceptance speech
U-2 incident Cold War frontier tension
First televised presidential debates as media frontier
Sit-in movement expands civil rights frontier

1962.description: Δw=+0.33 shows space frontier at apex of Cold War drama as Cuban Missile Crisis tests frontier resolve, John Glenn orbits Earth, and Kennedy commits nation to lunar frontier by decade's end.
key_manifestations: John Glenn first American to orbit Earth
Rachel Carson's 'Silent Spring' environmental frontier warning

1964.description: Δw=+0.32 reflects frontier mythology fragmenting as civil rights legislation passes while Vietnam escalation divides nation, with LBJ's Great Society as domestic frontier and Berkeley Free Speech Movement as protest frontier.
key_manifestations: Gulf of Tonkin Resolution Vietnam escalation
Marshall McLuhan's 'Understanding Media' as media frontier theory

1966.description: Δw=+0.29 shows frontier mythology challenged as Black Power rejects integrationist frontier, Star Trek imagines space as 'final frontier,' and counterculture seeks psychedelic frontier alternatives.
key_manifestations: Star Trek premieres with 'Space: the final frontier'
Black Panther Party founded in Oakland
National Organization for Women feminist frontier
LSD criminalized as psychedelic frontier closes

1968.description: Δw=+0.24 reflects frontier mythology in crisis as MLK and RFK assassinations, Tet Offensive, and Chicago Democratic Convention violence reveal frontier optimism's limits, while Apollo 8 orbits moon.
key_manifestations: Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert Kennedy assassinations
2001: A Space Odyssey cosmic frontier film

1969.description: Δw=+0.36 marks peak space frontier achievement as Apollo 11 moon landing fulfills Kennedy's New Frontier promise, while Woodstock and Stonewall riots signal countercultural and LGBTQ frontiers.
key_manifestations: ARPANET first message digital frontier origin

1970.description: Δw=+0.27 shows frontier mythology incorporating environmental consciousness as first Earth Day occurs and EPA created, while Kent State shootings reveal Vietnam frontier's domestic violence.
key_manifestations: Kent State shootings domestic frontier violence

1972.description: Δw=+0.22 reflects space frontier receding as Apollo program ends after Apollo 17, Nixon opens China frontier, and Watergate begins closing political frontier of trust.
key_manifestations: Nixon visits China opening diplomatic frontier
Title IX opens athletic frontier for women

1974.description: Δw=+0.16 shows frontier optimism declining as Nixon resigns, oil embargo reveals resource frontier limits, while personal computing frontier emerges with Altair and early homebrew computers.
key_manifestations: OPEC oil embargo resource frontier shock
ERISA pension reform economic security frontier

1976.description: Δw=+0.14 reflects bicentennial frontier nostalgia amid malaise as Apple Computer founded in garage embodying garage-frontier mythology, Viking lands on Mars, and Cray-1 advances computing frontier.
key_manifestations: Apple Computer founded by Jobs and Wozniak
Viking 1 Mars landing extends planetary frontier

1978.description: Δw=+0.12 shows frontier mythology in transition as California's Proposition 13 tax revolt signals economic frontier anxiety, while Bakke decision shapes affirmative action frontier.
key_manifestations: Bakke v. UC affirmative action frontier
Camp David Accords Middle East frontier

1980.description: Δw=+0.16 marks Reagan's frontier mythology revival promising 'morning in America' through deregulation, military buildup, and return to frontier individualism values, while CNN creates 24-hour news frontier.
key_manifestations: Ronald Reagan elected on frontier individualism platform
Mount St. Helens eruption natural frontier reminder

1982.description: Δw=+0.18 reflects Reagan frontier in economic recession as supply-side 'frontier' economics struggles, while personal computer becomes Time's 'Machine of the Year' signaling digital frontier.
key_manifestations: Time Magazine 'Machine of the Year' computer
Vietnam Veterans Memorial frontier sacrifice recognition
E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial suburban frontier film

1984.description: Δw=+0.20 shows digital frontier crystallizing as Apple Macintosh '1984' ad positions computing as liberation frontier, while Reagan's 'Morning in America' campaign revives frontier optimism.
key_manifestations: Breakdancing and hip-hop urban frontier culture

1986.description: Δw=+0.17 reflects space frontier tragedy and revival as Challenger disaster kills frontier teacher Christa McAuliffe, while Reagan's 'frontier in space' Star Wars program continues.
key_manifestations: Challenger disaster kills frontier teacher Christa McAuliffe
Strategic Defense Initiative 'Star Wars' space frontier
Immigration Reform Act frontier labor debate

1988.description: Δw=+0.15 shows frontier mythology in late Cold War as George H.W. Bush campaigns on Reagan frontier legacy, while early internet protocols establish digital frontier infrastructure.
key_manifestations: George H.W. Bush 'kinder, gentler nation' frontier
Morris Worm first major internet frontier attack
Die Hard as urban frontier action template

1990.description: Δw=+0.19 reflects post-Cold War frontier transformation as Berlin Wall falls opening new frontiers, Hubble Space Telescope extends cosmic frontier despite initial flaws, and World Wide Web invented.
key_manifestations: Tim Berners-Lee invents World Wide Web
Dances with Wolves revisionist frontier Western

1992.description: Δw=+0.18 shows digital frontier accelerating as World Wide Web opens to public, while Los Angeles riots reveal persistent racial frontier inequalities and 'Unforgiven' deconstructs Western frontier mythology.
key_manifestations: World Wide Web opens to public access
Los Angeles riots post-Rodney King verdict
Mall of America opens consumer frontier megastructure

1994.description: Δw=+0.21 reflects digital frontier commercializing as Netscape browser makes web accessible, while NAFTA opens trade frontier and 'Republican Revolution' channels frontier individualism.
key_manifestations: Amazon founded in Seattle garage frontier

1996.description: Δw=+0.24 shows Silicon Valley frontier ascendant as dot-com boom begins, John Perry Barlow's 'Declaration of the Independence of Cyberspace' proclaims digital frontier libertarianism.
key_manifestations: John Perry Barlow's 'Declaration of the Independence of Cyberspace'
Dolly the sheep cloning biotechnology frontier
Google founded at Stanford extending search frontier

1998.description: Δw=+0.27 reflects digital frontier mythology at height as dot-com valuations soar, iMac revives Apple's frontier design, and International Space Station begins new orbital frontier.
key_manifestations: Titanic film nostalgia for technological frontier tragedy

2000.description: Δw=+0.23 shows digital frontier bubble bursting as dot-com crash reveals speculative excess, while Human Genome Project completion opens genomic frontier and Florida recount tests democratic frontier.
key_manifestations: Y2K preparation reveals digital infrastructure frontier

2002.description: Δw=+0.20 reflects post-9/11 frontier anxiety as War on Terror projects frontier to Afghanistan and security state expands, while SpaceX founded signaling private space frontier.

2004.description: Δw=+0.22 shows frontier mythology in social media genesis as Facebook launches from Harvard dorm embodying tech frontier mythology, while Mars rovers Spirit and Opportunity extend planetary frontier.
key_manifestations: Mars rovers Spirit and Opportunity land
Bush Vision for Space Exploration moon-Mars frontier
Google IPO Silicon Valley frontier valuation

2006.description: Δw=+0.21 reflects Web 2.0 frontier democratizing as Twitter launches, YouTube acquired by Google, and 'An Inconvenient Truth' frames climate as existential frontier challenge.

2008.description: Δw=+0.19 shows frontier mythology in financial crisis as Lehman collapse reveals economic frontier fragility, while Obama's election promises new political frontier and iPhone transforms mobile frontier.
key_manifestations: Lehman Brothers collapse financial frontier crisis
Barack Obama elected as transformational frontier
iPhone App Store mobile frontier platform

2010.description: Δw=+0.22 reflects social media frontier maturing as Arab Spring demonstrates digital organizing power, iPad creates tablet frontier, and Tea Party channels frontier individualism against government.
key_manifestations: Deepwater Horizon oil spill environmental frontier disaster
Tea Party movement frontier individualism revival

2012.description: Δw=+0.24 shows private space frontier emerging as SpaceX Dragon first commercial spacecraft to ISS, while Curiosity Mars rover extends planetary frontier and Facebook IPO values social frontier.
key_manifestations: SpaceX Dragon first commercial ISS resupply
Curiosity rover Mars Science Laboratory landing
Facebook IPO social network frontier valuation
Higgs boson discovery particle physics frontier

2014.description: Δw=+0.26 reflects AI frontier accelerating as deep learning advances, while Rosetta comet landing extends space frontier and Ferguson protests reveal persistent racial frontier inequalities.
key_manifestations: Ferguson protests Black Lives Matter frontier
Amazon Echo voice assistant AI frontier

2016.description: Δw=+0.25 shows frontier mythology in populist revival as Trump's 'Make America Great Again' channels frontier nostalgia, while SpaceX lands first orbital rocket and AI beats humans at Go.
key_manifestations: SpaceX Falcon 9 first orbital rocket landing
AlphaGo defeats Lee Sedol AI frontier
Donald Trump elected on frontier nostalgia platform
LIGO gravitational wave detection cosmic frontier

2018.description: Δw=+0.27 reflects space frontier privatizing as SpaceX Falcon Heavy launches, while CRISPR gene editing controversy shows biotechnology frontier ethics and cryptocurrency frontier peaks and crashes.
key_manifestations: SpaceX Falcon Heavy Starman Tesla launch
Greta Thunberg climate frontier activism emerges

2020.description: Δw=+0.29 marks pandemic frontier transformation as COVID-19 closes physical frontiers while accelerating digital ones, SpaceX Crew Dragon returns human spaceflight to American soil, and remote work opens distributed frontier.
key_manifestations: SpaceX Crew Dragon Demo-2 first commercial human spaceflight
COVID-19 pandemic transforms work and social frontiers
George Floyd protests racial justice frontier

15_therapeutic_culture.name: Therapeutic Culture
15_therapeutic_culture.description: The rise of psychological frameworks replacing moral and religious ones - Philip Rieff's 'triumph of the therapeutic.' This cluster tracks how questions of virtue, sin, and character became questions of wellness, disorder, and self-actualization. The essay's concern about gambling, pornography, and addiction as moral problems that we can now only articulate as 'harm' reflects this shift: when therapeutic categories displace moral ones, objections based on dignity, honor, or character become inarticulable. The 'unable to make wise moral determinations' the essay diagnoses partly reflects therapeutic culture's displacement of moral vocabulary.

1880.description: Baseline Δw=0.0: Moral and religious frameworks dominate interpretation of human behavior. Sin, virtue, and character remain primary explanatory categories. Neurological research emerging but psychology not yet distinct discipline.
key_manifestations: William James begins teaching psychology at Harvard (1875)
Wilhelm Wundt's Leipzig laboratory establishes experimental psychology (1879)
George Beard coins 'neurasthenia' as nervous exhaustion diagnosis

1882.description: Minimal Δw=+0.005: Early stirrings of psychological vocabulary entering educated discourse. Hypnosis and suggestion gaining scientific attention in France. Moral categories still firmly dominant.
key_manifestations: Jean-Martin Charcot's hysteria demonstrations at Salpêtrière
G. Stanley Hall establishes first American psychology laboratory at Johns Hopkins
Friedrich Nietzsche's 'The Gay Science' questions moral foundations

1884.description: Incremental Δw=+0.005: Psychology begins institutional establishment. William James exploring consciousness scientifically. Religious frameworks still provide dominant moral vocabulary.
key_manifestations: William James publishes 'What is an Emotion?' in Mind journal
Bernheim-Charcot debate over hypnosis and suggestion
Francis Galton establishes anthropometric laboratory in London

1886.description: Gradual Δw=+0.005: Freud visits Charcot in Paris, absorbing ideas about unconscious processes. Nervous conditions increasingly medicalized while moral character still primary framework.
key_manifestations: Sigmund Freud studies with Charcot at Salpêtrière (1885-86)
Richard von Krafft-Ebing's 'Psychopathia Sexualis' medicalizes sexual deviance
Ernst Mach's 'Analysis of Sensations' influences psychology

1888.description: Steady Δw=+0.005: Psychological terminology spreading through medical journals. Concept of 'nervous breakdown' gaining currency. Moral vocabulary still dominant in public discourse.
key_manifestations: American Journal of Psychology founded by G. Stanley Hall
Freud translates Bernheim's work on hypnotic suggestion
Pierre Janet begins work on psychological automatism

1890.description: Notable Δw=+0.01: William James's 'Principles of Psychology' provides scientific vocabulary for mental life. Psychology establishing academic credibility while religious-moral frameworks remain dominant.
key_manifestations: William James publishes 'The Principles of Psychology'
James-Lange theory of emotion gains attention
First International Congress of Psychology in Paris

1892.description: Incremental Δw=+0.005: Psychology professionalizing with dedicated associations. Distinction between sin and sickness beginning to shift for certain conditions like alcoholism.
key_manifestations: American Psychological Association founded with G. Stanley Hall as president
Boris Sidis begins hypnosis research at Harvard
Wilhelm Wundt's 'Lectures on Human and Animal Psychology'

1894.description: Gradual Δw=+0.005: Freud and Breuer developing cathartic method. Psychological explanation of hysteria gaining ground. Character and virtue still dominant moral vocabulary.
key_manifestations: Breuer and Freud publish preliminary communication on hysteria
John Dewey begins psychological studies in Chicago
Margaret Floy Washburn first woman to earn psychology PhD

1896.description: Accelerating Δw=+0.01: Freud coins 'psychoanalysis.' Unconscious motivation entering scientific discourse. Beginning shift from moral will to psychological mechanism as explanatory framework.
key_manifestations: Freud first uses term 'psychoanalysis' in published work
Lightner Witmer establishes first psychological clinic at University of Pennsylvania
Studies on Hysteria by Breuer and Freud (1895)

1898.description: Steady Δw=+0.005: Child study movement applying psychological frameworks to development. Mental hygiene concepts emerging. Moral vocabulary still dominant in mainstream culture.
key_manifestations: Boris Sidis publishes 'The Psychology of Suggestion'
G. Stanley Hall's child study movement expanding

1900.description: Significant Δw=+0.015: 'The Interpretation of Dreams' introduces unconscious psychology to wider audience. Freud's framework offers alternative to moral explanations of behavior.
key_manifestations: Karl Pearson develops correlation coefficient for psychological research
Mental testing movement beginning with Binet's early work

1902.description: Growing Δw=+0.01: William James's 'Varieties of Religious Experience' subjects religion itself to psychological analysis. Beginning medicalization of spiritual experiences.
key_manifestations: William James delivers Gifford Lectures, publishes 'Varieties of Religious Experience'
Freud publishes 'The Psychopathology of Everyday Life'
Adolf Meyer arrives in America, promotes psychobiology

1904.description: Steady expansion Δw=+0.01: Psychology gaining institutional foothold in universities. Psychological vocabulary spreading among educated classes while mass culture retains moral frameworks.
key_manifestations: Ivan Pavlov receives Nobel Prize for work on conditioned reflexes
G. Stanley Hall publishes 'Adolescence' applying psychology to youth
First intelligence testing by Binet and Simon in France

1906.description: Incremental Δw=+0.01: Emmanuel Movement brings psychological healing into Protestant churches. Early attempt to synthesize therapeutic and religious frameworks.
key_manifestations: Emmanuel Movement founded at Emmanuel Church, Boston
Clifford Beers hospitalized, will write 'A Mind That Found Itself'

1908.description: Notable increase Δw=+0.02: Mental hygiene movement launches, medicalizing mental distress. Clifford Beers's memoir brings asylum conditions and psychological suffering to public attention.
key_manifestations: Clifford Beers publishes 'A Mind That Found Itself'
National Committee for Mental Hygiene founded
First Freudian psychoanalytic congress in Salzburg

1910.description: Accelerating Δw=+0.02: Freud's Clark University lectures introduce psychoanalysis to American audience. Unconscious motivation becoming respectable explanatory framework among intellectuals.
key_manifestations: Abraham Flexner's medical education report influences psychiatric training

1912.description: Steady Δw=+0.01: Adler and Jung break from Freud, creating multiple psychological schools. Psychology of religion emerging as academic field. Therapeutic vocabulary entering educated discourse.
key_manifestations: Alfred Adler founds Society for Individual Psychology
J.B. Watson begins behaviorist research at Johns Hopkins

1914.description: Pre-war plateau Δw=+0.01: Psychological concepts established in academic circles but limited mass penetration. War will soon demonstrate psychology's practical applications.
key_manifestations: John B. Watson's 'Behavior: An Introduction to Comparative Psychology'
Boston Psychopathic Hospital opens, Adolf Meyer as consultant

1916.description: War-driven Δw=+0.02: Shell shock forces military and medical establishment to acknowledge psychological trauma. Moral categories of cowardice giving way to medical diagnosis.
key_manifestations: Shell shock recognized as medical condition in British Army
Lewis Terman publishes Stanford-Binet intelligence test

1918.description: Major wartime Δw=+0.03: Mass psychological testing in US military normalizes mental measurement. Psychology proves practical utility. War neuroses challenge purely moral view of courage.
key_manifestations: Army Alpha and Beta tests administered to 1.75 million recruits
Smith-Sears Veterans Rehabilitation Act addresses psychological casualties
W.H.R. Rivers treats shell shock at Craiglockhart

1920.description: Postwar expansion Δw=+0.03: Psychological vocabulary entering popular culture. Watson's behaviorism promises scientific control of human behavior. 'Adjustment' becoming key therapeutic concept.
key_manifestations: John B. Watson and Rosalie Rayner's 'Little Albert' experiment
First child guidance clinics established in America

1922.description: Continued growth Δw=+0.02: Psychoanalysis entering American mainstream through magazines and popular books. Mental hygiene movement expanding. Therapeutic vocabulary spreading.
key_manifestations: Reader's Digest founded, will spread psychological advice
Émile Coué's self-improvement method gains American following
Child Welfare League of America founded

1924.description: Steady Δw=+0.02: Psychology applied to child-rearing, advertising, industrial management. Behavioral adjustment replacing moral character as parenting goal among progressive classes.
key_manifestations: John B. Watson's 'Behaviorism' published for popular audience
Mary Cover Jones demonstrates deconditioning of fear
First Rorschach tests administered in America

1926.description: Expanding Δw=+0.02: Psychological advice columns appearing in popular magazines. Parent education movement applying mental hygiene principles. 'Maladjustment' entering common vocabulary.
key_manifestations: Parents Magazine founded, spreading psychological child-rearing advice
National Committee for Mental Hygiene expands
Karen Horney begins psychoanalytic practice in Berlin

1928.description: Continued Δw=+0.02: Watson's child-rearing manual brings behaviorist psychology to middle-class parents. Psychological expertise beginning to displace traditional moral guidance.
key_manifestations: John B. Watson publishes 'Psychological Care of Infant and Child'
Margaret Mead's 'Coming of Age in Samoa' relativizes psychological norms

1930.description: Depression-era shift Δw=+0.02: Economic crisis creates mass psychological distress. Freud's 'Civilization and Its Discontents' frames culture itself as source of neurosis.
key_manifestations: White House Conference on Child Health and Protection
First psychiatric social work training programs

1932.description: Modest Δw=+0.01: Depression focuses attention on economic rather than psychological explanations. Mental hygiene movement continues but economic crisis dominates public discourse.
key_manifestations: Karen Horney emigrates to Chicago, brings neo-Freudian perspective
Gordon Allport teaching personality psychology at Harvard

1934.description: Gradual Δw=+0.01: Alcoholics Anonymous precursors forming. Addiction beginning shift from moral failure to disease concept. Psychological perspective infiltrating religion through pastoral counseling.
key_manifestations: Oxford Group influences AA founders Bill Wilson and Dr. Bob Smith
Ruth Benedict's 'Patterns of Culture' relativizes psychological norms
Anton Boisen establishes clinical pastoral education

1936.description: Steady Δw=+0.01: Dale Carnegie's self-help approach merges psychological techniques with success culture. Ego psychology developing more adaptive, less moralistic framework.
key_manifestations: Dale Carnegie publishes 'How to Win Friends and Influence People'
Anna Freud's 'The Ego and the Mechanisms of Defense'

1938.description: Pre-war Δw=+0.01: Electroconvulsive therapy introduced, reinforcing medical model of mental illness. B.F. Skinner's behaviorism offers non-moral, mechanistic view of human action.
key_manifestations: Electroconvulsive therapy introduced by Cerletti and Bini

1940.description: Early war Δw=+0.02: Military psychiatry expanding. Psychological screening of recruits institutionalizes mental measurement. Character giving way to personality assessment.
key_manifestations: US Army begins mass psychological screening of recruits

1942.description: Wartime acceleration Δw=+0.03: Military psychiatry demonstrates psychology's practical applications. 'Combat fatigue' and 'war neurosis' replace moral categories for breakdown under fire.
key_manifestations: William Menninger heads Army psychiatry, expands services
OSS uses psychological assessment for agent selection

1944.description: Major wartime Δw=+0.03: GI Bill will fund mass expansion of psychology training. Psychological casualties legitimized as medical condition deserving treatment not stigma.
key_manifestations: GI Bill passes, will fund psychology graduate training
Army film 'Let There Be Light' documents psychiatric treatment

1946.description: Postwar surge Δw=+0.04: National Mental Health Act establishes federal commitment to mental health. Psychology professionalizing rapidly. Veterans' psychological needs legitimize therapy.
key_manifestations: National Mental Health Act signed by Truman
Benjamin Spock publishes 'Baby and Child Care'
Viktor Frankl's 'Man's Search for Meaning' (German edition)

1948.description: Continued expansion Δw=+0.03: World Health Organization defines health to include mental well-being. Kinsey Report subjects sexuality to scientific rather than moral analysis.
key_manifestations: Alfred Kinsey publishes 'Sexual Behavior in the Human Male'
World Health Organization constitution defines health broadly

1950.description: Midcentury normalization Δw=+0.03: Erik Erikson's developmental psychology replaces moral stages with psychological ones. 'Adjustment' becomes central therapeutic goal.
key_manifestations: David Riesman's 'The Lonely Crowd' analyzes social character
American Psychiatric Association begins DSM development

1952.description: Diagnostic standardization Δw=+0.02: First DSM published, standardizing psychological categories. Chlorpromazine discovered, reinforcing medical model of mental illness.
key_manifestations: Norman Vincent Peale's 'The Power of Positive Thinking'

1954.description: Tranquilizer era begins Δw=+0.02: Miltown introduces era of anti-anxiety medication. Psychological distress becomes pharmaceutical problem. Abraham Maslow developing humanistic alternative.

1956.description: Organizational psychology Δw=+0.02: William Whyte's 'Organization Man' critiques conformity in psychological terms. Corporate America adopting psychological management techniques.
key_manifestations: Albert Ellis develops Rational Emotive Therapy

1958.description: Pre-sixties Δw=+0.02: Humanistic psychology emerging as 'third force.' Rollo May bringing existential psychology to American audience. Questions of meaning framed psychologically.
key_manifestations: Rollo May's 'Existence: A New Dimension in Psychiatry and Psychology'

1960.description: Early sixties Δw=+0.02: First oral contraceptive approved, enabling sexual revolution that separates sexuality from moral frameworks. Thomas Szasz challenges psychiatric authority.
key_manifestations: Thomas Szasz's 'The Myth of Mental Illness'

1962.description: Humanistic emergence Δw=+0.02: Esalen Institute founded, launching human potential movement. Abraham Maslow promoting self-actualization over adjustment. Therapeutic goals expanding.
key_manifestations: Esalen Institute founded in Big Sur
Abraham Maslow's 'Toward a Psychology of Being'
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest published by Ken Kesey

1964.description: Counterculture stirrings Δw=+0.02: Eric Berne's transactional analysis brings therapeutic concepts to mass audience. Timothy Leary promoting psychedelics as psychological tools.
key_manifestations: Eric Berne's 'Games People Play' becomes bestseller
Timothy Leary dismissed from Harvard, continues LSD advocacy
Community Mental Health Centers Act implementation

1966.description: Therapeutic expansion Δw=+0.02: Masters and Johnson publish on human sexuality, further medicalizing intimate life. Encounter groups spreading through educated classes.
key_manifestations: Thomas Harris begins writing 'I'm OK - You're OK'
National Training Laboratories spreads encounter groups

1968.description: Late sixties Δw=+0.02: DSM-II published, homosexuality still listed as disorder. Philip Rieff's 'Triumph of the Therapeutic' names and critiques emerging culture.
key_manifestations: Philip Rieff's 'The Triumph of the Therapeutic'
Fritz Perls brings Gestalt therapy to Esalen

1970.description: Early seventies Δw=+0.02: Primal Scream therapy, EST, and other therapies proliferating. Self-actualization replacing adjustment as therapeutic goal. Me Decade emerging.
key_manifestations: Feminist consciousness-raising groups apply therapeutic model to politics

1972.description: Therapeutic culture consolidating Δw=+0.02: 'I'm OK - You're OK' bestseller. EST founded by Werner Erhard. Psychology colonizing self-understanding of educated classes.
key_manifestations: Thomas Harris's 'I'm OK - You're OK' dominates bestseller lists
Werner Erhard founds EST (Erhard Seminars Training)
George McGovern's vice presidential candidate Thomas Eagleton withdraws over psychiatric history

1974.description: Diagnostic shifts Δw=+0.02: APA votes to remove homosexuality from DSM, demonstrating psychiatric categories as contested cultural terrain. Self-help publishing booming.
key_manifestations: American Psychiatric Association removes homosexuality from DSM
Robert Pirsig's 'Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance'

1976.description: Me Decade consolidation Δw=+0.02: Tom Wolfe names 'Me Decade,' identifying therapeutic self-focus. Christopher Lasch beginning critique of narcissistic culture.
key_manifestations: Tom Wolfe's 'The Me Decade and the Third Great Awakening'
Gail Sheehy's 'Passages' applies developmental psychology to adult life

1978.description: Late seventies Δw=+0.01: Self-help industry maturing. Recovery movement emerging from alcoholism treatment. Therapeutic language becoming common in everyday speech.
key_manifestations: M. Scott Peck begins writing 'The Road Less Traveled'
Jonestown massacre raises questions about therapeutic cult dynamics
DSM-III development with Robert Spitzer leading

1980.description: Diagnostic expansion Δw=+0.02: DSM-III massively expands psychiatric categories. PTSD officially recognized. Psychological conditions proliferating as explanatory frameworks.
key_manifestations: M. Scott Peck's 'The Road Less Traveled' begins bestseller run

1982.description: Early eighties Δw=+0.01: Codependency concept emerging from addiction treatment. Adult Children of Alcoholics movement framing family dysfunction therapeutically.
key_manifestations: Adult Children of Alcoholics movement grows
Codependency concept spreads from addiction treatment
John Bradshaw begins family systems workshops

1984.description: Recovery culture expanding Δw=+0.01: Twelve-step programs multiplying beyond alcoholism. 'Dysfunctional family' entering common vocabulary. Inner child concept developing.
key_manifestations: Overeaters Anonymous, Sex Addicts Anonymous expanding
Alice Miller's 'Thou Shalt Not Be Aware' influences recovery movement

1986.description: Prozac era dawning Δw=+0.01: Fluoxetine approved as Prozac. SSRI revolution will make pharmacological treatment mainstream. Self-esteem movement in schools expanding.
key_manifestations: California Task Force on Self-Esteem established
John Bradshaw's 'Healing the Shame That Binds You'

1988.description: Recovery bestsellers Δw=+0.01: Bradshaw, Melody Beattie bestsellers bring recovery concepts to mass audience. 'Codependent No More' sells millions. Therapeutic vocabulary mainstream.
key_manifestations: John Bradshaw's 'Bradshaw On: The Family' PBS series

1990.description: Peak recovery movement Δw=+0.01: Twelve-step culture at peak influence. Inner child workshops proliferating. Robert Bly's mythopoetic men's movement applies therapy to masculinity.
key_manifestations: Robert Bly's 'Iron John' applies therapy to masculinity crisis
John Bradshaw's 'Homecoming: Reclaiming and Championing Your Inner Child'

1992.description: Self-esteem culture Δw=+0.01: Self-esteem as educational goal institutionalized. Oprah's book club spreading therapeutic reading. Talk shows as mass therapy.
key_manifestations: Clarissa Pinkola Estés's 'Women Who Run with the Wolves'
Daniel Goleman begins emotional intelligence research

1994.description: DSM expansion continues Δw=+0.01: DSM-IV further expands categories. Emotional intelligence concept emerging. Therapeutic frameworks applied to workplace.
key_manifestations: Herrnstein and Murray's 'The Bell Curve' controversy

1996.description: Emotional intelligence Δw=+0.005: Goleman's 'Emotional Intelligence' brings concept mainstream. Self-help industry mature and diversifying. Prozac Nation published.

1998.description: Positive psychology emerges Δw=+0.005: Martin Seligman launches positive psychology, shifting from pathology to flourishing. Pharmaceutical advertising normalizing medication.
key_manifestations: Martin Seligman's APA presidential address launches positive psychology
Spencer Johnson's 'Who Moved My Cheese?' applies therapy to workplace

2000.description: Millennial therapeutic culture Δw=+0.005: Therapy fully normalized among educated classes. Dr. Phil launching as mass therapist. ADHD diagnoses expanding.
key_manifestations: Dr. Phil McGraw launches TV show
ADHD medication prescriptions surge in children

2002.description: Positive psychology mainstream Δw=+0.005: Seligman's 'Authentic Happiness' brings positive psychology to popular audience. Happiness science emerging as field.

2004.description: Facebook era begins Δw=+0.005: Social media will create new psychological phenomena. Eckhart Tolle's spiritual-therapeutic synthesis spreading. Mindfulness entering mainstream.
key_manifestations: Facebook founded, will reshape psychological experience
Eckhart Tolle's 'The Power of Now' spreads through Oprah
Jon Kabat-Zinn's mindfulness-based stress reduction expands

2006.description: Wellness industry expanding Δw=+0.005: 'The Secret' brings law of attraction to mass audience. Wellness as lifestyle concept. Twitter launched, accelerating psychological self-disclosure.
key_manifestations: Twitter launched, enabling public mood expression
TED talks spreading psychological concepts globally

2008.description: Digital therapy emerging Δw=+0.005: Financial crisis creates mass anxiety. iPhone apps enabling digital self-tracking. Mindfulness apps beginning development.
key_manifestations: Financial crisis creates mass psychological distress
iPhone app ecosystem launches, enabling wellness apps
Brené Brown's shame and vulnerability research spreads

2010.description: Vulnerability culture Δw=+0.005: Brené Brown's TED talk on vulnerability goes viral. DSM-5 development controversial. Instagram launched, creating new anxiety vectors.
key_manifestations: Brené Brown's 'The Power of Vulnerability' TED talk viral
Instagram launched, will affect body image psychology
Mindfulness apps Headspace, Calm in development

2012.description: Mindfulness mainstream Δw=+0.005: Meditation apps launching. Corporate wellness programs expanding. Psychological safety entering management vocabulary.
key_manifestations: Headspace app launches, brings meditation mainstream
Sheryl Sandberg's 'Lean In' applies psychology to gender

2014.description: Trigger warning culture Δw=+0.005: Campus trigger warnings and safe spaces institutionalizing therapeutic concepts. Mental health awareness campaigns ubiquitous.
key_manifestations: Ice Bucket Challenge shows social media mental health activism
Calm app reaches millions of downloads

2016.description: Self-care as politics Δw=+0.005: 'Self-care' becomes political slogan. Therapy as routine for educated classes. 'The Coddling of the American Mind' critiques therapeutic excess.
key_manifestations: Jonathan Haidt and Greg Lukianoff's Atlantic article on coddling

2018.description: Near-total Δw=+0.005: Therapeutic vocabulary completely dominant in public discourse. 'Trauma,' 'boundaries,' 'toxic' as everyday terms. Moral language nearly displaced.
key_manifestations: Haidt and Lukianoff's 'The Coddling of the American Mind' book
Rachel Hollis's 'Girl, Wash Your Face' bestseller
Mental health days normalized in workplaces

2020.description: Plateau at saturation Δw=0.0: COVID-19 pandemic normalizes therapy discourse completely. 'Collective trauma,' 'pandemic anxiety' as universal frames. Therapeutic categories fully displace moral vocabulary - inability to articulate gambling, pornography, addiction concerns except as 'harm' reflects complete triumph of therapeutic over moral framework.
key_manifestations: COVID-19 pandemic universalizes mental health discourse
Mental health content dominates social media

16_credentialism_expertise.name: Credentialism & Expertise Culture
16_credentialism_expertise.description: This cluster tracks the displacement of practical wisdom, apprenticeship knowledge, and virtue-based judgment by formal credentials, expert certification systems, and professional gatekeeping. The Δw patterns show steady accumulation through professionalization movements (1880-1920), acceleration during the rise of research universities and technocratic governance (1940-1970), and explosive growth during credential inflation (1980-2010), with recent partial reversal as populist backlash against 'expert authority' emerges alongside the very IRB-style proceduralism that makes credentials necessary for institutional action.

1880.description: Professions remain largely apprenticeship-based. Medicine, law, and ministry represent early professional forms, but entry barriers are minimal and practical experience dominates over formal credentials.
key_manifestations: Proprietary medical schools with minimal standards

1882.description: Early stirrings of professional organization. Medical societies begin advocating for licensing requirements, though enforcement remains weak.

1884.description: Johns Hopkins medical school reforms begin reshaping medical education toward scientific credentials. Professional boundaries start hardening.

1886.description: American Federation of Labor founding signals credentialing pressure extending to trades. Professional associations multiply across fields.

1888.description: Graduate education expands as German university model gains influence. PhD becomes marker of scholarly authority.

1890.description: Progressive Era begins driving credentialism as reform tool. Expertise framed as antidote to corruption and incompetence.

1892.description: American Psychological Association founded, marking credentialization of new domains. University presidents gain cultural authority.

1894.description: Economic depression highlights tension between expert economic theories and lived hardship. Credentialed authorities questioned by populists.

1896.description: McKinley victory consolidates business-expert alliance. Scientific management ideas begin spreading, requiring credentialed efficiency experts.

1898.description: Spanish-American War highlights military credentialism needs. Colonial administration requires trained experts.

1900.description: New century brings surge of professionalization. Flexner begins medical education investigations. City manager movement starts.

1902.description: Muckraking journalism increases calls for expert oversight. Bureau of Corporations established, requiring economic expertise.

1904.description: Roosevelt administration embraces expert governance. Conservation movement requires scientific credentials for land management.

1906.description: Pure Food and Drug Act creates expert regulatory apparatus. Carnegie Foundation begins funding professionalization studies.

1908.description: Harvard Business School founded, credentializing management. FBI established with professional investigation standards.

1910.description: Flexner Report revolutionizes medical credentialing, closing proprietary schools. This becomes template for professional gatekeeping across fields.

1912.description: Wilson campaign promises expert governance. Children's Bureau established with social work credentials required. IQ testing begins.

1914.description: Federal Reserve establishes monetary expert authority. World War I preparation requires credentialed mobilization planners.

1916.description: National Research Council formed, institutionalizing scientific expertise for policy. Professional licensing expands across states.

1918.description: World War I massively expands credentialed expertise for mobilization. Army Alpha tests credential millions. Expert planning valorized.
key_manifestations: Public health expert authority in flu

1920.description: Postwar reaction against Wilsonian expert idealism, but credential infrastructure remains. Business expertise ascendant over government expertise.

1922.description: Credential inflation visible as college enrollment climbs. Professional associations consolidate licensing victories.

1924.description: Immigration restriction uses expert eugenic credentialing. Business schools multiply. Expertise becomes conservative force.

1926.description: SAT introduced, credentializing college access through expert-designed testing. Professional sports emerge with credentialed management.

1928.description: Hoover's engineer-president candidacy peaks expert authority. Technocratic governance seems triumphant. Credential inflation continues.

1930.description: Depression discredits economic experts initially. But response requires new expert apparatus. Credential authority temporarily questioned.

1932.description: Brain Trust model brings academic experts into governance. New Deal requires massive credentialed bureaucracy. Expert planning rehabilitated.

1934.description: New Deal agencies hire thousands of credentialed experts. SEC, FCC, NLRB require specialized expertise. Expert governance infrastructure explodes.

1936.description: Expert opinion polling emerges with Gallup. Social Security requires actuarial credentials. Credential culture half-established by mid-century.

1938.description: Fair Labor Standards Act requires expert wage determination. FDA authority expands requiring more scientific credentials.

1940.description: War mobilization preparation renews expert planning demands. Military-academic complex begins forming. Scientific credentials militarized.

1942.description: Total war requires total expertise. Manhattan Project exemplifies credentialed scientific authority. Military-academic complex solidifies.

1944.description: GI Bill promises mass credentialization. Bretton Woods establishes international expert monetary governance. Postwar expert order designed.

1946.description: Veterans flood universities, democratizing credential access while reinforcing credential necessity. Atomic energy requires extreme expert gatekeeping.

1948.description: Cold War intensifies demand for credentialed expertise in security, science, area studies. Expert consensus becomes patriotic duty.

1950.description: NSF established, institutionalizing scientific credential authority. Korean War expands military-credentialed complex. Management credentials boom.

1952.description: Eisenhower campaigns partly on practical military wisdom vs. egghead expertise, but governs with expert councils.

1954.description: Oppenheimer case shows expert authority limits under political pressure. But credential infrastructure continues expanding.

1956.description: Organization Man culture normalizes credential-based careers. White collar credential requirements proliferate.

1958.description: Sputnik crisis triggers massive credential expansion. NDEA funds science and language credentials. Expert authority becomes national security imperative.

1960.description: Best and Brightest era begins. Kennedy administration celebrates credentialed expertise. Defense intellectuals ascendant. McNamara's whiz kids.

1962.description: Cuban Missile Crisis seems to validate expert crisis management. Credential prestige at peak. But cracks visible in expert Vietnam advice.

1964.description: Great Society programs require massive expert bureaucracy. War on Poverty uses credentialed planners. Civil Rights Act enforcement needs legal expertise.

1966.description: Vietnam escalation based on expert advice begins generating backlash. Credibility gap emerges. But domestic credential requirements keep growing.

1968.description: Expert authority in crisis. Vietnam, urban riots challenge expert planning. Wallace and Nixon campaign against expert establishment. But credentialism persists.

1970.description: Environmental and consumer movements create new expert regulatory domains. EPA, OSHA require credentialed personnel. Expert authority shifts domains.

1972.description: Credential inflation intensifies as Vietnam-era graduates flood job market. Title IX creates compliance credential requirements. Expert systems expand.

1974.description: Post-Watergate reforms create new expert oversight requirements. IRB system for human subjects research begins expanding. Compliance credentials multiply.

1976.description: Carter campaigns as outsider but governs with credentials. Stagflation challenges economic expert consensus. Professional licensing peaks in scope.

1978.description: Deregulation movement challenges some expert domains but creates others. Proposition 13 signals credential-class resentment. Common Rule for human subjects.

1980.description: Reagan revolution rhetorically attacks expert government but credential requirements continue growing. Business credentials valorized over government credentials.

1982.description: Credential culture crosses symbolic threshold. College degree becomes baseline for middle class. Healthcare credentialing expands dramatically.

1984.description: Yuppie culture celebrates credentialed professional success. Business school applications soar. Expert systems begin computerization.

1986.description: Challenger disaster shows expert system failures but response is more credentialed oversight. IRB requirements expand further.

1988.description: Credential requirements for jobs continue inflating. Advanced degrees increasingly required for entry-level positions. Expert panels multiply.

1990.description: End of Cold War reduces some defense credentials but expands others. International expert institutions ascendant. Credential culture globalizes.

1992.description: Clinton administration brings credentialed experts back explicitly. Healthcare reform attempt shows expert planning ambition. Ross Perot channels anti-expert sentiment.

1994.description: Republican revolution campaigns against credentialed government but expands regulatory credentials. Internet begins disrupting expert gatekeeping.

1996.description: Welfare reform requires new expert administration. Internet expands but credentialed gatekeeping adapts. Credential inflation accelerates.

1998.description: Expert consensus on globalization, technology policy peaks. But internet creates alternative knowledge networks. Credential requirements keep growing.

2000.description: Florida recount shows expert vote-counting authority contested. Dot-com bust challenges tech expert predictions. But credential requirements unaffected.

2002.description: Post-9/11 security creates massive new expert credential requirements. Intelligence expert systems expand. Homeland Security bureaucracy emerges.

2004.description: Iraq WMD failures discredit expert intelligence but credential systems persist. Education testing credentials expand under No Child Left Behind.

2006.description: Financial engineering credentials peak before crisis. Expert complexity in derivatives creates systemic risk. IRB requirements at maximum expansion.

2008.description: Financial crisis massively discredits economic expert consensus. But response is more expert intervention. Credential culture deeply shaken but reinforced.

2010.description: ACA creates massive healthcare credential requirements. Tea Party channels anti-expert populism. Credential inflation continues despite economic crisis.

2012.description: Data science credentials emerge as new expert domain. MOOCs briefly threaten credential gatekeeping but are absorbed. Expert systems more algorithmic.

2014.description: Credential inflation reaches absurdity as masters degrees required for entry positions. Anti-expert populism builds. Online credentials contested.

2016.description: Trump election represents credential authority crisis. Expert consensus rejected on trade, immigration, climate. But credential requirements undiminished.

2018.description: Expert authority increasingly contested in polarized environment. But credential gatekeeping strengthens in institutions. IRB-style proceduralism spreads.

2020.description: Pandemic creates expert authority crisis and reinforcement simultaneously. Public health credentials contested while required. Credential culture at maximum tension between populist rejection and institutional gatekeeping, exemplifying how IRB-style proceduralism makes credentials necessary for any institutional action while practical wisdom is systematically displaced.

17_consumerist_hedonism.name: Consumerist Hedonism
17_consumerist_hedonism.description: The elevation of pleasure, comfort, and consumption as life's central purpose - what the essay implies in its critique of 'mere life' as insufficient goal. This cluster tracks the transformation from producer to consumer society, from character formation to lifestyle curation, from sacrifice to self-indulgence. The 'laissez-faire acquiescence' the essay criticizes - 'People want convenience, personalization, cheap entertainment; markets provide' - reflects consumerist hedonism's triumph as default philosophy.

1880.description: Δw establishes baseline as Victorian producerism dominates; consumption remains morally suspect, thrift exalted as virtue. Department stores like Macy's and Wanamaker's begin seducing middle-class shoppers but pleasure-seeking carries stigma of moral weakness.
key_manifestations: Wanamaker's Grand Depot Philadelphia (1876) as proto-consumer temple
Thorstein Veblen born 1857, future theorist of conspicuous consumption
Protestant ethic of deferred gratification still hegemonic

1882.description: Δw increases marginally as electrical illumination transforms shopping into spectacle. Edison's Pearl Street Station (1882) enables lit storefronts that extend consumption's temporal reach into evening hours, making pleasure-seeking literally more visible.
key_manifestations: Edison's Pearl Street Station electrifies lower Manhattan (1882)
Marshall Field's Chicago expands with gas and electric lighting
Advertising Age begins slow emergence from pure information to desire-creation

1884.description: Δw registers early mail-order catalogs as democratization of desire. Montgomery Ward catalog (founded 1872) reaches rural America with images of goods previously unimaginable, training eyes to want beyond local availability.
key_manifestations: Montgomery Ward catalog expands to 240 pages

1886.description: Δw marks Coca-Cola's invention (1886) as emblematic commodity - pure refreshment divorced from nutrition, pleasure as product. Sears, Roebuck founded same year, completing mail-order infrastructure that would train generations in consumption-as-aspiration.
key_manifestations: Coca-Cola invented by John Pemberton in Atlanta (1886)
Avon Products founded as California Perfume Company (1886)

1888.description: Δw advances as Kodak camera ('You press the button, we do the rest') invents leisure consumption - experience itself becomes purchasable commodity. George Eastman's slogan inaugurates convenience as selling point over skill.
key_manifestations: Kodak camera released with 'You press the button' slogan (1888)
Financial Times founded, tracking commercial expansion
Thomas Edison's phonograph enables purchased entertainment

1890.description: Δw reflects William James's 'Principles of Psychology' (1890) providing scientific framework for understanding desire and habit - knowledge advertisers would exploit. Sherman Antitrust Act paradoxically enables corporate consolidation strategies.
key_manifestations: How the Other Half Lives by Jacob Riis shows consumption's underside

1892.description: Δw increases as Veblen begins formulating conspicuous consumption theory at University of Chicago. General Electric formed (1892), consolidating electrical infrastructure that would power consumer society's expansion.
key_manifestations: General Electric Company formed through merger (1892)
Veblen joins University of Chicago economics department

1894.description: Δw stalls during economic depression of 1893-1897; Pullman Strike reveals class tensions underlying consumer dreams. Milton Hershey begins chocolate production, democratizing luxury previously reserved for elites.

1896.description: Δw recovers as first modern Olympic Games (Athens 1896) spectacularize leisure. William McKinley's 'full dinner pail' campaign promises consumption as political platform - material comfort enters democratic discourse as entitlement.
key_manifestations: First modern Olympic Games in Athens (1896)

1898.description: Δw advances with Spanish-American War creating new markets while Caleb Bradham invents Pepsi-Cola. Yellow journalism demonstrates media's power to manufacture desire - for war, for goods, for sensation itself.

1900.description: Δw accelerates at century's turn as Veblen's 'Theory of the Leisure Class' (1899) anatomizes consumption's social logic. Kodak Brownie camera ($1, 1900) democratizes image-capture, enabling middle-class participation in memory-as-commodity.

1902.description: Δw registers Macy's move to Herald Square (1902), creating retail cathedral architecture. Air conditioning invented (1902) - Willis Carrier's technology would eventually enable enclosed shopping environments divorced from nature's rhythms.
key_manifestations: Macy's moves to Herald Square, world's largest store (1902)
Willis Carrier invents modern air conditioning (1902)

1904.description: Δw increases as St. Louis World's Fair displays consumer abundance. Ice cream cone invented at fair, exemplifying pleasure-foods displacing sustenance. First New York subway enables urban consumption mobility.
key_manifestations: St. Louis World's Fair/Louisiana Purchase Exposition (1904)
Ice cream cone popularized at St. Louis Fair

1906.description: Δw reflects Pure Food and Drug Act (1906) - paradoxically enabling consumer trust that accelerates consumption. Upton Sinclair's 'The Jungle' exposes production but reinforces consumption's innocence as sphere of freedom.
key_manifestations: Kellogg's Corn Flakes national distribution begins

1908.description: Δw jumps with Model T Ford (1908) inaugurating automobile as consumer object par excellence - freedom, status, pleasure combined. General Motors founded same year, beginning automotive competition that would define American consumption.
key_manifestations: Murad cigarette ads pioneer lifestyle advertising

1910.description: Δw advances as department store culture reaches apex. Selfridges London (1909) and others make shopping respectable female leisure activity. First electric washing machine (Thor, 1908) promises domestic liberation through consumption.

1912.description: Δw registers Titanic disaster (1912) as cautionary tale of luxury's hubris, temporarily checking hedonistic excess. Yet L.L. Bean founded same year, outdoor consumption emerging as authentic alternative to urban shopping.

1914.description: Δw dips as World War I disrupts consumption's expansion. Yet war economy ironically prepares mass production techniques that will enable post-war consumer explosion. Federal Reserve (1913) creates monetary infrastructure for consumer credit.

1916.description: Δw continues war-related decline as production for combat displaces consumer goods. Yet Piggly Wiggly (1916) invents self-service grocery, eliminating clerk mediation - consumer autonomy increases even during restriction.
key_manifestations: Piggly Wiggly opens first self-service grocery (1916)
Nathan's Famous hot dogs founded at Coney Island (1916)

1918.description: Δw begins recovery as war ends; influenza pandemic (1918-1919) paradoxically emphasizes bodily pleasure's fragility, creating post-war urgency toward enjoyment. Advertising sophistication increases during war through propaganda techniques.
key_manifestations: War propaganda techniques available for commercial use

1920.description: Δw surges as Roaring Twenties begin; Prohibition paradoxically eroticizes consumption by making alcohol forbidden pleasure. First commercial radio broadcast (KDKA, 1920) creates advertising medium that enters homes directly.
key_manifestations: KDKA Pittsburgh first commercial radio broadcast (1920)
19th Amendment - women's suffrage expands consumer citizenship

1922.description: Δw accelerates dramatically as consumer credit expands. Reader's Digest (1922) curates consumption of ideas; Emily Post's 'Etiquette' (1922) codifies consumption manners. Shopping becomes American lifestyle's defining activity.
key_manifestations: First shopping center: Country Club Plaza, Kansas City (1922)

1924.description: Δw continues rising as installment buying democratizes consumption beyond savings. General Motors Acceptance Corporation (1919) model spreads - buy now, pay later transforms temporal relationship to desire and gratification.

1926.description: Δw reflects advertising's psychological sophistication. Edward Bernays applies Freudian theory to marketing; his 'torches of freedom' campaign (1929 coming) will link cigarettes to women's liberation. NBC network formed (1926), nationalizing desire.

1928.description: Δw peaks pre-crash as consumer culture reaches 1920s zenith. Herbert Hoover promises 'chicken in every pot, car in every garage' - consumption becomes official American dream. Bubble psychology inflates material expectations.

1930.description: Δw crashes with stock market; Depression delegitimizes pure consumption as American telos. Yet advertising persists, and Hostess Twinkies (1930) offer cheap pleasure. Consumer desire doesn't disappear - it becomes shameful, frustrated.
key_manifestations: Stock market crash aftermath, Depression deepens

1932.description: Δw continues declining at Depression's nadir. Radio provides free entertainment, sustaining hedonistic infrastructure. Zippo lighter (1932) exemplifies affordable luxury - small pleasures persist amid deprivation.

1934.description: Δw stabilizes as New Deal attempts recovery. Ritz Crackers (1934) named after luxury hotels - aspirational naming for Depression-era products. Shirley Temple offers escapist entertainment, pleasure through spectatorship.
key_manifestations: Shirley Temple becomes top box office star

1936.description: Δw recovers modestly as 'Life' magazine (1936) creates visual consumption of lifestyle imagery. Dale Carnegie's 'How to Win Friends' (1936) commodifies personality itself - self becomes product for social marketplace.
key_manifestations: Dale Carnegie's 'How to Win Friends and Influence People' (1936)
Volkswagen Beetle designed for mass consumption

1938.description: Δw inches upward; Fair Labor Standards Act creates weekend leisure time for consumption. Ballpoint pen invented, DuPont nylon announced (1938) - synthetic materials promise abundance through chemistry.
key_manifestations: Fair Labor Standards Act creates 40-hour week (1938)
Snow White first feature-length Disney animation (1937)

1940.description: Δw dips as war preparation begins redirecting production. Yet war economy will create pent-up demand and savings that explode post-war. McDonald's founded (1940), though expansion waits for peacetime.
key_manifestations: Nylon stockings create consumer frenzy before rationing

1942.description: Δw declines sharply under wartime rationing; Victory Gardens transform consumption into patriotic production. Yet advertising maintains consumer desire through 'when peace comes' promises - building post-war appetite.
key_manifestations: Wartime rationing of sugar, coffee, gasoline, meat
Victory Gardens encourage production over consumption

1944.description: Δw stabilizes as war's end approaches; GI Bill (1944) promises post-war consumption boom through education and housing benefits. Consumer culture waits in wings, advertising preparing population for peacetime spending.
key_manifestations: Seventeen magazine launched (1944) - teen consumer market
War bond campaigns teach mass marketing

1946.description: Δw surges dramatically as post-war consumer explosion begins. Baby boom creates family-oriented consumption; Tupperware (1946) and home parties pioneer social shopping. Pent-up demand and savings unleash unprecedented buying.

1948.description: Δw continues rapid ascent; McDonald's Speedee Service System (1948) invents fast food. First cable TV systems; LP records revolutionize music consumption. Levittown embodies suburban consumption lifestyle.

1950.description: Δw crosses majority threshold as consumerism becomes American identity. Diners Club (1950) creates first credit card; shopping plazas multiply. David Riesman's 'The Lonely Crowd' (1950) diagnoses 'other-directed' consumption-oriented personality.
key_manifestations: First shopping centers proliferate in suburbs

1952.description: Δw advances as television enters majority of homes, delivering advertising directly to living rooms. Holiday Inn founded (1952), standardizing travel consumption. Mr. Potato Head first toy advertised on TV.
key_manifestations: TV in majority of American homes
Mr. Potato Head first TV-advertised toy (1952)

1954.description: Δw rises as TV dinners (Swanson, 1954) merge food with television, eating becoming entertainment accompaniment. Color TV broadcasting begins; McDonald's franchising revolutionizes consumer food delivery.
key_manifestations: Ray Kroc joins McDonald's, begins franchising (1954)

1956.description: Δw advances with Interstate Highway Act (1956) enabling automobile-centered consumption. Southdale Center (1956) creates first fully enclosed shopping mall - climate-controlled consumption divorced from weather and season.
key_manifestations: Elvis Presley on Ed Sullivan - youth consumer culture

1958.description: Δw continues climbing as Bank of America launches BankAmericard (future Visa, 1958), democratizing credit. John Kenneth Galbraith's 'The Affluent Society' (1958) critiques production for consumption's sake - critique itself becomes consumed.

1960.description: Δw reflects Kennedy's consumer-friendly image; Vance Packard's 'The Waste Makers' (1960) exposes planned obsolescence. First Wal-Mart planning begins; oral contraceptive approved, enabling consumption of sexuality itself.

1962.description: Δw advances as discount retail revolutionizes; Walmart, Kmart, and Target all open first stores in 1962. Kennedy establishes Consumer Bill of Rights - consumption becomes civic right. Pop Art elevates consumer objects to high culture.

1964.description: Δw reflects Beatles-driven youth consumption culture; British Invasion commodifies rebellion. Marshall McLuhan's 'Understanding Media' (1964) theorizes consumption of media itself. G.I. Joe creates action figure market.
key_manifestations: Beatles on Ed Sullivan, British Invasion (1964)

1966.description: Δw increases modestly as counterculture paradoxically creates new consumer markets - hippie fashion, psychedelic posters, underground records. Guy Debord's 'Society of the Spectacle' (1967) theorizes consumption as total social relation.
key_manifestations: Star Trek debuts, creating merchandising empire

1968.description: Δw dips slightly amid social upheaval; consumer confidence shaken by assassinations, Vietnam, riots. Yet '2001: A Space Odyssey' imagines corporate future; McDonald's Big Mac introduced, standardizing pleasure.
key_manifestations: '2001: A Space Odyssey' - corporate space future

1970.description: Δw recovers as first Earth Day (1970) paradoxically commodifies environmentalism. Bell-bottoms and platform shoes show counterculture absorbed into fashion consumption. Consumer protection legislation proliferates.

1972.description: Δw advances as HBO (1972) pioneers subscription entertainment - paying for TV itself, not just advertised products. Nike founded (1972), beginning athletic brand culture. Pong creates video game consumption.

1974.description: Δw declines during oil crisis and stagflation; long gas lines reveal consumption's vulnerability. Yet this scarcity increases desire - when abundance returns, consumption accelerates. People magazine (1974) commodifies celebrity itself.

1976.description: Δw rebounds as Bicentennial celebration commercializes patriotism. Apple Computer founded (1976), personal computing begins consumer journey. VHS format wins, enabling home movie consumption.
key_manifestations: VHS format released for home video

1978.description: Δw rises as disco culture epitomizes hedonistic consumption - clothes, drugs, nightlife as lifestyle. Airline deregulation democratizes travel consumption. Garfield comic strip (1978) creates licensing empire.

1980.description: Δw accelerates with Reagan era beginning; CNN 24-hour news (1980) creates continuous media consumption. Post-It Notes (1980) exemplify disposable convenience products. Cable TV fragments audiences into consumer niches.

1982.description: Δw advances as MTV (1981) transforms music into visual consumption. USA Today (1982) applies TV aesthetics to print - McNews for McMerica. First CD players enable digital music consumption transition.

1984.description: Δw jumps with Apple Macintosh '1984' Super Bowl ad - advertising as entertainment event. PG-13 rating creates new consumer demographic. Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles begin toy-driven entertainment.
key_manifestations: Transformers and G.I. Joe cartoons as toy advertisements

1986.description: Δw reflects yuppie culture's unashamed materialism. Oprah Winfrey show goes national, creating consumption advice platform. Fox Broadcasting launches, fragmenting audiences further. Home Shopping Network expands cable shopping.

1988.description: Δw rises as prozac approved (1987), pharmacological mood management becoming consumer choice. Nike 'Just Do It' campaign (1988) links consumption to self-actualization. Mall of America planned.
key_manifestations: Prozac approved (1987) - mood as consumer product

1990.description: Δw advances as Cold War end promises global consumer expansion. Seinfeld (1989) makes urban consumption comedic subject matter. Tim Berners-Lee invents World Wide Web (1989), infrastructure for future e-commerce.
key_manifestations: Cold War ends, global markets open

1992.description: Δw continues rising as Mall of America opens (1992) - consumption's ultimate temple. Costco merger creates warehouse consumption model. Reality TV begins with 'The Real World' (1992), consuming others' lives as entertainment.
key_manifestations: MTV's 'The Real World' pioneers reality TV (1992)

1994.description: Δw accelerates as Amazon founded (1994), beginning e-commerce revolution that will transform consumption entirely. Starbucks expands nationally, commodifying coffee culture. Friends sitcom celebrates urban consumption lifestyle.

1996.description: Δw rises as dot-com boom promises frictionless consumption. eBay (1995) enables peer-to-peer consumer transactions. DVD format launches, superior home video consumption. Fox News launches, consumption of political identity.

1998.description: Δw approaches 0.90 as Google founded (1998), organizing world's information for consumption. iMac revolutionizes computer as lifestyle object. Viagra approved (1998) - sexual performance becomes pharmaceutical consumer product.

2000.description: Δw dips slightly with dot-com crash, but consumer infrastructure survives. Reality TV explosion with Survivor (2000) - consuming others' struggles as entertainment. Napster challenges music consumption model.

2002.description: Δw recovers as post-9/11 patriotic consumption urged - 'go shopping' as civic duty. American Idol (2002) combines consumption with participation. Xbox Live (2002) creates online gaming consumption ecosystem.

2004.description: Δw advances as Facebook launches (2004), beginning social media consumption era. Netflix expands DVD-by-mail, training consumers for streaming future. Podcast term coined, democratizing audio content consumption.

2006.description: Δw rises as Twitter and YouTube (2005-2006) enable infinite content consumption. Wii console (2006) gamifies physical activity. Amazon Prime (2005) creates subscription consumption loyalty.

2008.description: Δw drops with financial crisis exposing credit-fueled consumption's fragility. Yet iPhone (2007) has already transformed consumption into constant connectivity. Crisis delegitimizes excess but not consumption itself.

2010.description: Δw rebounds as iPad (2010) creates tablet consumption category. Instagram (2010) makes image-sharing consumption compulsive. Netflix begins streaming pivot, unlimited entertainment for monthly fee.

2012.description: Δw rises as smartphone penetration creates constant consumption access. Spotify launches in US (2011), unlimited music streaming. Facebook IPO values attention monetization. Seamless/delivery apps transform food consumption.

2014.description: Δw advances as Amazon Prime expands to video, creating total consumption ecosystem. Uber transforms transportation consumption. Ice Bucket Challenge shows viral philanthropy as consumption performance.

2016.description: Δw continues rising as Amazon Echo/Alexa (2014) brings voice-activated consumption into homes. Pokemon Go (2016) merges physical and digital consumption. Subscription boxes (Blue Apron, etc.) curate consumption decisions.

2018.description: Δw approaches plateau as Netflix reaches 130 million subscribers; streaming wars begin. Influencer marketing makes consumption indistinguishable from content. TikTok acquisition (2017) accelerates short-form consumption.

2020.description: Δw reaches near-maximum as pandemic forces total e-commerce adoption. Amazon becomes essential infrastructure; streaming services multiply (Disney+, HBO Max). Physical retail collapses accelerate. 'Laissez-faire acquiescence' complete - convenience, personalization, cheap entertainment delivered algorithmically to isolated consumers.

18_risk_aversion_culture.name: Risk Aversion Culture
18_risk_aversion_culture.description: The progressive prioritization of safety over achievement, protection over aspiration - the cultural transformation C.S. Lewis diagnosed when he called courage 'the form of every virtue at the testing point.' This cluster tracks how the ancient ideal of the statesman gave way to the manager, how 'the manager's virtue is not courage or imagination, but competence.' Physical-world progress stalled partly because 'we have grown hesitant to the point of timidity.' From helicopter parenting to regulatory precaution to safetyism on campus, this cluster tracks courage's displacement by risk management.

1880.description: Victorian self-reliance paradigm at peak; Horatio Alger Jr.'s 'rags to riches' novels celebrate risk-taking entrepreneurship. Δw minimal as frontier ethos and industrial daring define cultural virtue.
key_manifestations: Horatio Alger's 'From Farm to Fortune' serialization
Edison's Menlo Park laboratory culture of experimental risk

1882.description: Robber baron era celebrates audacious capital risk; Carnegie expanding steel empire through aggressive speculation. Δw flat as risk-taking remains valorized cultural mode.
key_manifestations: Standard Oil Trust formation under Rockefeller
Edison's Pearl Street Station electrification gamble
Chinese Exclusion Act as rare federal protective measure

1884.description: First stirrings of labor protection; Bureau of Labor Statistics established. Δw shows initial institutional acknowledgment that unregulated risk creates casualties.
key_manifestations: Knights of Labor membership surge to 700,000

1886.description: Haymarket Affair creates first mass anxiety about industrial progress; American Federation of Labor founded. Δw increases as labor casualties become visible public concern.
key_manifestations: American Federation of Labor founding under Gompers

1888.description: Great Blizzard of 1888 spurs infrastructure protection thinking; early building codes emerge in urban centers. Δw stable as industrial optimism still dominates.
key_manifestations: George Eastman's Kodak democratizes risk-free amateur photography

1890.description: Sherman Antitrust Act first federal economic risk mitigation; frontier officially closed per Census Bureau. Δw rises as physical frontier closure begins psychological closing.
key_manifestations: Jacob Riis 'How the Other Half Lives' documents industrial human cost

1892.description: Homestead Strike violence shocks middle class; Ellis Island opens with medical inspection protocols. Δw shows early medicalization of risk assessment.
key_manifestations: Ellis Island medical inspection station opens
Sierra Club founding by John Muir

1894.description: Pullman Strike federal intervention; Labor Day becomes national holiday acknowledging worker vulnerability. Δw increases as state assumes protective role.
key_manifestations: Pullman Strike and federal troop deployment

1896.description: Plessy v. Ferguson institutionalizes 'separate but equal' as paternalistic protection framework. Δw stable as protective rhetoric masks exclusion.
key_manifestations: William Jennings Bryan 'Cross of Gold' speech on economic protection

1898.description: Spanish-American War briefly revives martial risk culture; Theodore Roosevelt's Rough Riders celebrated. Δw dips as imperial adventure temporarily valorizes physical courage.

1900.description: Galveston Hurricane kills 8,000; spurs first major disaster preparedness thinking. Δw rises sharply as natural catastrophe reveals infrastructure vulnerability.
key_manifestations: Galveston Hurricane deadliest US natural disaster
International Ladies Garment Workers Union founded

1902.description: Anthracite Coal Strike brings federal mediation; Roosevelt's 'Square Deal' emerges as protective politics. Δw increases as presidential activism addresses industrial danger.
key_manifestations: Newlands Reclamation Act for western water safety

1904.description: General Slocum disaster kills 1,021 in New York harbor; maritime safety regulations follow. Δw stable but accumulating regulatory responses to visible deaths.
key_manifestations: Roosevelt creates Department of Commerce and Labor

1906.description: Pure Food and Drug Act and Meat Inspection Act landmark safety legislation; Upton Sinclair's 'The Jungle' makes industrial danger visceral. Δw jumps as muckraking journalism weaponizes disgust.
key_manifestations: Pure Food and Drug Act passage

1908.description: Federal Employers Liability Act establishes railroad worker protections; Model T democratizes automobile risk. Δw high as federal liability framework emerges.
key_manifestations: Ford Model T mass production begins
Muller v. Oregon upholds protective labor legislation

1910.description: Mann Act moral protection; Bureau of Mines created after string of disasters. Δw rises as protective state expands across moral and physical domains.

1911.description: Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire kills 146; watershed moment for workplace safety movement. Δw spikes dramatically as visible female deaths galvanize reform.
key_manifestations: First state workmen's compensation laws spread

1913.description: Federal Reserve created for financial stability; Seventeenth Amendment democratizes Senate selection. Δw high as systemic risk management institutionalizes.
key_manifestations: Department of Labor created as cabinet agency

1914.description: Federal Trade Commission for consumer protection; Clayton Antitrust Act strengthens economic safety net. Δw rises as WWI begins revealing industrial war's unprecedented lethality.

1916.description: Keating-Owen Child Labor Act (later struck down); National Park Service protects natural heritage. Δw stable at elevated level as Progressive Era peaks.
key_manifestations: Federal Farm Loan Act agricultural protection

1918.description: Spanish Flu pandemic reveals public health vulnerability; WWI casualties trauma transforms attitudes toward organized violence. Δw jumps as mass death reshapes risk perception.

1920.description: Prohibition as moral protection project; Women's suffrage promises 'civilizing' influence. Δw dips slightly as Roaring Twenties risk appetite emerges.

1922.description: Jazz Age celebrates liberation from Victorian caution; speculation fever grows. Δw decreases as post-war hedonism embraces risk-taking.
key_manifestations: Reader's Digest founded for safe information consumption
Teapot Dome scandal reveals regulatory failure

1924.description: Immigration Act of 1924 restricts entry for 'protection'; insurance industry expands dramatically. Δw rises slightly as nativist protection intensifies.
key_manifestations: Immigration Act of 1924 national origins quotas
J. Edgar Hoover appointed FBI director
Life insurance industry reaches $90 billion coverage

1926.description: Air Commerce Act first aviation safety regulation; Miami hurricane kills 400, prompts building codes. Δw stable as new technologies create new regulatory domains.

1928.description: Kellogg-Briand Pact renounces war; speculative optimism peaks before crash. Δw dips as prosperity breeds complacency about systemic risk.

1930.description: Stock market crash aftermath; Smoot-Hawley Tariff as economic protection; bank failures spread panic. Δw spikes as Depression traumatizes risk perception generation.
key_manifestations: Dust Bowl begins in Great Plains

1932.description: Bonus Army dispersal shows state violence against citizens; FDR campaigns on security promises. Δw peaks as Depression desperation demands protection.

1934.description: Securities Exchange Commission created; Federal Housing Administration insures mortgages; Social Security debates begin. Δw rises as New Deal institutionalizes systematic risk mitigation.

1935.description: Social Security Act landmark safety net legislation; Wagner Act protects unions; Rural Electrification Administration. Δw jumps dramatically as federal safety net fundamentally restructures American life.

1937.description: Hindenburg disaster ends airship era; Fair Labor Standards Act debates; 'Roosevelt Recession' validates caution. Δw high as safety concerns terminate promising technology.

1938.description: Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act strengthens FDA; Fair Labor Standards Act establishes minimum wage and maximum hours. Δw rises as New Deal safety architecture completes.

1940.description: Wartime mobilization requires risk acceptance; selective service reinstates martial obligation. Δw dips as existential threat demands courage over caution.

1942.description: Wartime sacrifice normalizes danger; Japanese internment as 'protective' measure. Δw decreases as war necessitates risk tolerance.
